revision.comment: /* Arguments against the changes */ Corrected typo busy -> bust
revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=March 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2018}} [[File:2018 UK higher education strike placards .jpg|thumb|2018 UK higher education strike placards]]
The [[University and College Union]] (UCU), a trade union representing 110,000 staff at UK universities,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ucu.org.uk/article/1685/About-UCU|title=About UCU|website=www.ucu.org.uk|language=en-gb|access-date=2018-03-28}}</ref> began a strike on 22 February 2018 as part of an [[industrial action]] against 64 universities, represented by [[Universities UK]] (UUK). The dispute concerned proposed changes to the [[Universities Superannuation Scheme]] (USS).<ref name=":1">{{Cite web |url=https://www.ucu.org.uk/article/9242/UCU-announces-14-strike-dates-at-61-universities-in-pensions-row |title=UCU announces 14 strike dates at 61 universities in pensions row |website=www.ucu.org.uk |language=en-gb|access-date=12 March 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180305150446/https://www.ucu.org.uk/article/9242/UCU-announces-14-strike-dates-at-61-universities-in-pensions-row |archivedate=5 March 2018 |df=}}</ref>
The first wave of strike action escalated over fourteen strike days between 22 February to 20 March, and took place at sixty-four universities across the UK.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":5">{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/education-43140729 |title=University strike: What's it all about? |last=Burns |first=Judith |date=21 February 2018 |work=BBC News|access-date=12 March 2018 |language=en-GB |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180227005517/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/education-43140729 |archivedate=27 February 2018 |df=}}</ref> This was the longest-ever strike in UK higher-education history.<ref name=":11">{{Cite web |url=https://www.wired.co.uk/ |title=WIRED UK - Future Science, Culture & Technology News and Reviews |website=www.wired.co.uk|access-date=20 March 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180226094835/http://www.wired.co.uk/ |archivedate=26 February 2018 |df=}}</ref>
An estimated 42,000 staff<ref name=":12" /> went on strike with 575,000 teaching hours being lost.<ref name=":13">{{Cite news|url=https://www.timeshighereducation.com/news/pensions-strike-forces-uk-universities-reset-examinations|title=Pensions strike forces UK universities to reset examinations|date=2018-03-28|work=Times Higher Education (THE)|access-date=2018-03-28|language=en}}</ref> By 28 March, over 700 external examiners had also recorded their resignations in a UCU document.<ref name=":14">{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/education/education-news/university-strikes-pensions-dispute-lecturers-students-ucu-college-union-uuk-a8278486.html|title=New university strike dates announced|date=2018-03-28|work=The Independent|access-date=2018-03-28|language=en-GB}}</ref>
As of 28 March 2018, more than a million students were estimated to have been affected,<ref name=":13" /> with 126,000 students signing petitions calling for fee refunds.<ref name=":101">{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/education-43295334|title=University talks resume after Twitter row|last=Burns|first=Judith|date=6 March 2018|work=BBC News|language=en-GB|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180312192658/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/education-43295334|archivedate=12 March 2018|deadurl=no|access-date=12 March 2018|df=}}</ref> Students also occupied campus buildings in support of striking staff at more than a dozen universities.<ref name=":1" /><ref name="auto1">{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/education-43295334|title=University strike talks resume after Twitter skirmishes|last=Burns|first=Judith|date=6 March 2018|work=BBC News|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180305225924/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/education-43295334|archivedate=5 March 2018|deadurl=no|access-date=6 March 2018|df=}}</ref>
The action has been called "something of a milestone" for "impending service sector strikes of the 21st century".<ref name="auto">Thomas Hale, '[https://ftalphaville.ft.com/2018/02/22/2198956/the-strange-economics-of-the-university-strikes/ The strange economics of the university strikes] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180309054440/https://ftalphaville.ft.com/2018/02/22/2198956/the-strange-economics-of-the-university-strikes/|date=9 March 2018}}', ''Financial Times'' (22 February 2018).</ref> ''[[Times (newspaper)|The Times]]'' described the strikes as "the worst industrial action at universities in modern times".<ref name=":12">{{cite web |url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/university-lecturers-to-strike-as-students-sit-summer-exams-2jmmxlsbx |title=University lecturers to strike as students sit summer exams |last=Correspondent |first=Nicola Woolcock, Education CorrespondentNicola Woolcock, Education |date=9 March 2018 |work=The Times|access-date=12 March 2018 |language=en |issn=0140-0460}}</ref>
==Background to the strike== [[File:Non-staff costs as a proportion of universities' total expenditure UK average 2006-15, according to Higher Education Statistics Agency.svg|thumb|Non-staff costs as a proportion of universities' total expenditure: UK average 2006-15, rising from around 42% to around 45%, according to the [[Higher Education Statistics Agency]].]] [[File:UK university pay and student income, inflation-adjusted to 2017 prices, 2006-16.svg|thumb|UK university pay and student income, 2006-16, inflation-adjusted to 2017 prices. Over the period, total spending per student rises by around £2000; vice-chancellors' remuneration rises by £21873; professors' pay falls by £7544; and average pay across all academic staff falls by £4304.]] The United Kingdom has 130 universities.<ref name=":5" /> Staff at 68 universities founded before 1992 are members of the USS pension scheme.<ref name=":5" /> (Most academic staff at institutions which became universities ''after'' 1992 are members of the Teachers' Pension Scheme, which is unaffected by this dispute.)<ref name=":5" /> In January 2018, UCU members at 61 universities (initially) balloted in favour of action over the proposed pension changes.<ref name="auto8" />
As reporting, both in the UK and abroad, noted, the strikes took place in the context of other tensions over higher education and pension provision in the UK, as follows.<ref name="auto2">'[https://www.ft.com/content/4671a4c0-163d-11e8-9376-4a6390addb44 Striking dons add to UK students’ resentments] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180225072257/https://www.ft.com/content/4671a4c0-163d-11e8-9376-4a6390addb44 |date=25 February 2018 }}', ''The Financial Times'' (20 February 2018).</ref><ref>Richard Adams, '[https://www.theguardian.com/education/2018/feb/16/theresa-may-details-tuition-fee-overhaul Theresa May to reveal details of tuition fee overhaul on Monday] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180227001156/https://www.theguardian.com/education/2018/feb/16/theresa-may-details-tuition-fee-overhaul |date=27 February 2018 }}', ''The Guardian'' (16 February 2018).</ref><ref>Sebastian Borger, '[www.fr.de/wissen/grossbritannien-professoren-wollen-universitaeten-lahmlegen-a-1452510 Professoren wollen Universitäten lahmlegen]', ''Frankfurther Rundschau'', 74.44 (21 February 2018), p. 23.</ref><ref>Daniel Zylbersztajn, '[http://www.taz.de/Professoren-Streik-in-Grossbritannien/!5484269/ Stillstand an den Unis] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180222211945/http://taz.de/Professoren-Streik-in-Grossbritannien/!5484269/ |date=22 February 2018 }}', ''Taz'' (22 February 2018).</ref><ref>Steven Parfitt, '[https://jacobinmag.com/2018/02/britain-university-strike-pensions Lecturers on Strike] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180312173520/https://www.jacobinmag.com/2018/02/britain-university-strike-pensions |date=12 March 2018 }}', ''Jacobin'' (21 February 2018).</ref>
===National UK higher education policy===
* Debates about [[Tuition fees in the United Kingdom|tuition fee]] levels and the mechanisms for paying them. In particular, on 19 February, the UK Prime Minister [[Theresa May]] had announced an official review of UK higher education funding.<ref>Sean Coughlan, '[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/education-43106736 Theresa May's university review will not scrap fees] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180226002838/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/education-43106736 |date=26 February 2018 }}', BBC News (19 February 2018).</ref> * The increasingly corporate and privatised character of higher education institutions. For example, universities, whose capital expenditure had traditionally been funded to a significant extent by government funding, were increasingly participating in private capital markets, with new levels of concern for their credit ratings and with uncertain consequences for their finances and governance.<ref name="auto"/><ref>Thomas Hale, '[https://ftalphaville.ft.com/2018/03/06/2199103/universities-and-the-allure-of-capital-markets/ Universities and the allure of capital markets] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180307090725/https://ftalphaville.ft.com/2018/03/06/2199103/universities-and-the-allure-of-capital-markets/ |date=7 March 2018 }}', ''Financial Times'' (6 March 2018).</ref> * The creation of the [[Office for Students]] on 1 January 2018, whose powers came into force 1 April 2018. For example, on 28 February 2018, the OFS said that "universities that fail to mitigate the impact of the strikes would open themselves up to regulatory intervention".<ref>Harry Yorke, 'Universities told they face fines if strikes harm students', ''The Daily Telegraph'' (27 February 2018), 2.</ref>
===Pensions=== ====The USS pension scheme====
The USS scheme was created in 1974 to provide sector-wide pensions for UK university staff (focusing on academic staff).<ref name="Logan1985">Douglas Logan, ''The Birth of a Pension Scheme. A History of the Universities Superannuation Scheme'' (Liverpool University Press 1985).</ref> Its terms changed little until 2011, when major reforms were implemented, followed by further changes in 2014-15.<ref name="Platanakis2015">Emmanouil Platanakis and Charles Sutcliffe, 'Asset–Liability Modelling and Pension Schemes: The Application of Robust Optimization to USS', ''The European Journal of Finance'' (2015), 1-29, [[Digital object identifier|doi]]:[https://doi.org/10.1080%2F1351847X.2015.1071714 10.1080/1351847X.2015.1071714].</ref><ref name="Platanakis2018">Emmanouil Platanakis and Charles Sutcliffe, 'Pension Schemes, Taxation and Stakeholder Wealth: The USS Rule Changes', ICMA Centre, Discussion Paper Number: ICM-2017-08 (23 January 2018): https://ssrn.com/abstract=3039364; {{DOI|10.2139/ssrn.3039364}}.</ref><ref name="TimesGrove2015">Jack Grove, '[https://www.timeshighereducation.com/news/new-uss-pension-reform-plans-to-be-put-to-union-vote/2017987.article New USS Pension Reform Plans to be Put to Union Vote] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180215143632/https://www.timeshighereducation.com/news/new-uss-pension-reform-plans-to-be-put-to-union-vote/2017987.article |date=15 February 2018 }}', ''Times Higher Education'' (15 January 2015).</ref> These changes left scheme members markedly worse off: one academic study concluded that the reduced wealth of post-2011 entrants was equivalent to an 11% drop in their total compensation or a 13% drop in their salaries.<ref name="Platanakis2016">Emmanouil Platanakis and Charles Sutcliffe, 'Pension Scheme Redesign and Wealth Redistribution Between the Members and Sponsor: The USS Rule Change in October 2011', ''Insurance: Mathematics and Economics'', 69 (2016), 14–28. {{DOI|10.1016/j.insmatheco.2016.04.001}}</ref>{{rp|25}}
By 2017, the USS scheme had over 400,000 members.<ref name="Economist2017">'[https://www.economist.com/news/britain/21725794-their-position-independent-institutions-funded-public-cash-awkward-one-universities Universities’ main pension pot faces the biggest deficit of any British fund] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180215204047/https://www.economist.com/news/britain/21725794-their-position-independent-institutions-funded-public-cash-awkward-one-universities |date=15 February 2018 }}', ''The Economist'' (3 August 2017).</ref>
====Wider UK pensions====
* The UK [[Pensions Act 2004]] had placed stringent requirements on private-sector pensions to ensure that their liabilities could be met even if all their member organisations collapsed at once—which in the context of USS would entail the whole University system going bust, an event deemed unlikely by many. Over 2006-17, the proportion of UK private-sector defined-benefit schemes open to new joiners declined from 43% to 14%.<ref name="ucu.org.uk">'[https://www.ucu.org.uk/media/9556/Backing-for-defined-benefit-pension-scheme-bucks-trend-Financial-Times---27-Sep-2018/pdf/Backing_for_defined_benefit_pension_scheme_bucks_trend___Financial_Times.pdf Backing for defined benefit pension scheme bucks trend]', ''The Financial Times'' (5 October 2018).</ref> In the analysis of [[Mervyn King, Baron King of Lothbury|Mervyn King]] and [[John Kay (economist)|John Kay]], 'The 2004 Pensions Act is a prime, but by no means unique, example of well-intentioned but inept financial regulation. Over-prescriptive, it has led to the demise of the defined benefit schemes that it was designed to protect. If proposed changes to the USS are implemented, there will be no defined benefit schemes of any significant size outside the public sector open to new members'.<ref name="timeshighereducation.com">Mervyn King and John Kay, '[https://www.timeshighereducation.com/features/uss-crisis-can-pension-system-be-reformed USS crisis: can the pension system be reformed?]', ''Times Higher Education'' (6 September 2018), https://www.johnkay.com/2018/09/06/uss-crisis-can-the-pension-system-be-reformed/.</ref> * Similar or even more dramatic proposed pension cuts for universities' non-academic staff.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.pensions-expert.com/DB-Derisking/Southampton-uni-s-DB-closure-proposal-poorly-timed-experts-say?ct=true |title=Southampton uni's DB closure proposal poorly timed, experts say |last=Imeson |first=Sophia |date=16 January 2018 |work=Pensions Expert|access-date=18 March 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180319085008/http://www.pensions-expert.com/DB-Derisking/Southampton-uni-s-DB-closure-proposal-poorly-timed-experts-say?ct=true|archive-date=19 March 2018|dead-url=no |df=}}</ref> For example, in January 2018, [[University of Southampton|Southampton University]] began consultations on closing its defined-benefits pension scheme for non-academic staff,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.professionalpensions.com/professional-pensions/news/3024438/southampton-uni-support-staff-face-two-thirds-pension-cut |title=Southampton Uni support staff 'face two-thirds pension cut' |last=Phillips |first=James |date=15 January 2018 |work=Professional Pensions|access-date=18 March 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180115162756/https://www.professionalpensions.com/professional-pensions/news/3024438/southampton-uni-support-staff-face-two-thirds-pension-cut|archive-date=15 January 2018|dead-url=no |df=}}</ref> and in March 2018, [[Staffordshire University]] began consultations on moving support staff from the defined-benefit local government scheme to a local defined-contribution scheme.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.stokesentinel.co.uk/news/stoke-on-trent-news/hundreds-university-staff-braced-pension-1329336 |title=Hundreds of university staff braced for pension changes |last=McInnes |first=Kathie |date=12 March 2018 |work=The Sentinel|access-date=18 March 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180319213536/https://www.stokesentinel.co.uk/news/stoke-on-trent-news/hundreds-university-staff-braced-pension-1329336|archive-date=19 March 2018|dead-url=no |df=}}</ref> * Worsening outlooks for pension provision across the UK, in the context of rising remuneration for fund managers and increasing integration of pension funds into speculative financial markets.<ref>E.g. Christine Berry, '[https://www.opendemocracy.net/neweconomics/uss-tip-iceberg-pensions-system-hot-mess/ USS is the tip of the iceberg. Our pensions system is a hot mess] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180316071735/https://www.opendemocracy.net/neweconomics/uss-tip-iceberg-pensions-system-hot-mess/ |date=16 March 2018 }}', ''OpenDemocracy'' (1 March 2018).</ref> For example, it was noted that pay for USS's chief executive rose from £484,000 in 2017 to £566,000 in 2018, while two staff members earned over £1m, and running costs stood at £125m per annum.<ref>Sean Coughlan, '[www.bbc.co.uk/news/education-43157711 University pension boss's £82,000 pay rise]', ''BBC News'' (22 February 2018).</ref>
===Pay and conditions===
* Public concern about rapidly rising pay for University senior management, particularly [[Vice-chancellor]]s.<ref name="auto3">Phoebe Braithwaite, '[https://www.wired.co.uk/article/university-pensions-ucu-uss-academics-strike The university pensions strike is a last resort for STEM academics] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180307043115/http://www.wired.co.uk/article/university-pensions-ucu-uss-academics-strike |date=7 March 2018 }}', ''Wired'' (23 February 2018).</ref> In particular, on 26 February, the Channel 4 investigative journalism programme ''Dispatches'' broadcast an exposé of vice-chancellors' expenses claims.<ref>Jamie Doward, '[https://www.theguardian.com/media/2018/feb/24/vice-chancellors-expenses-scandal-channel-4-dispatches-universities Revealed: British university vice-chancellors’ five-star expenses] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180226114015/https://www.theguardian.com/media/2018/feb/24/vice-chancellors-expenses-scandal-channel-4-dispatches-universities |date=26 February 2018 }}', ''The Guardian'' (24 February 2018).</ref> * Concern among university staff about falling real-terms pay for most staff.<ref name="auto3"/> Moreover, the pay projections assumed in USS's 2017 valuation and used to argue for reducing pensions assumed an increase in general pay growth: rather than assuming pay would keep up with inflation (as measured by the [[consumer price index]]), USS assumed pay growth one percent above inflation (as measured, more generously, by the [[retail price index]]).<ref>D. Spiegelhalter and others, '[https://www.ft.com/content/810aa034-9c79-11e7-8cd4-932067fbf946 Examining the Numbers on Pension Valuation]', ''The Financial Times'' (19 September 2017); available at https://www.dannydorling.org/?p=6109 and http://www.dannydorling.org/wp-content/files/dannydorling_publication_id6103.pdf.</ref> On 16 April 2018, staff were actually offered a payrise of 1.7%, below both CPI inflation (then 2.7%) and RPI (then 3.6%).<ref>Jack Grove, '[https://www.timeshighereducation.com/news/uk-university-staff-offered-17-cent-pay-rise-2018-19 UK university staff offered 1.7 per cent pay rise for 2018-19]', ''Times Higher Education'' (16 April 2016).</ref> * Growing numbers of academic staff were on [[Precarity|precarious]] short-term or zero-hours contracts – 54% in 2016 according to figures from UCU (disputed by employers).<ref name="auto3"/> In March, UCU argued on the basis of data from a [[Freedom of information in the United Kingdom|freedom of information]] request that an average of 27% UK university teaching hours were delivered by such staff.<ref>Sophie Inge, '[https://www.timeshighereducation.com/news/uk-universities-rely-casual-staff-half-teaching UK universities rely on casual staff ‘for up to half of teaching’] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180321192832/https://www.timeshighereducation.com/news/uk-universities-rely-casual-staff-half-teaching |date=21 March 2018 }}', ''Times Higher Education'' (6 March 2016).</ref> The issue of casualisation became increasingly prominent in UCU members' understanding of the strikes as they developed.<ref name="auto4">Sophie Inge, '[https://www.timeshighereducation.com/news/genie-out-bottle-casualisation-after-pension-strikes ‘Genie out of the bottle’ on casualisation after pension strikes] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180321192830/https://www.timeshighereducation.com/news/genie-out-bottle-casualisation-after-pension-strikes |date=21 March 2018 }}', ''Times Higher Education'' (21 March 2018).</ref> * Casualisation of university staff more widely was also reflected in a strike by cleaners, porters, and receptionists seeking to get their work insourced at the [[University of London]], called during the first wave of UCU strikes for 25–26 April.<ref>Sanjana Varghese, '[https://londonstudent.coop/news/2018/03/16/cleaners-announce-biggest-ever-strike-for-outsourced-workers-in-higher-education/ Cleaners announce biggest ever strike for outsourced workers in Higher Education] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180322143304/https://londonstudent.coop/news/2018/03/16/cleaners-announce-biggest-ever-strike-for-outsourced-workers-in-higher-education/ |date=22 March 2018 }}', ''London Student'' (16 March 2018).</ref> * Similar concerns were reflected by strike action around the same time more widely in UK professional classes: junior doctors undertook [[Junior doctors contract dispute in England, 2015|their first strikes]] in the history of the [[National Health Service (England)]] in 2015-16, while barristers began strike action on 1 April 2018.<ref>'[https://economist.com/news/britain/21741202-barristers-lecturers-and-doctors-are-among-those-feeling-pinch-british-professionals-revolt British professionals revolt as austerity hits the middle class]', ''The Economist'' (26 April 2018).</ref>
====Ballot concerning joint higher education trade union national pay claim==== Concern about pay and conditions, particularly in relation to high senior pay and expenditure on new buildings in the face of declining staff pay, the gender pay gap, precarious contracts and casualisation, and workloads were all expressed as part of the wider context of the pensions dispute, but also formed the basis of ballots for industrial action across all UK higher education unions: [[UNISON]], [[Unite the Union|Unite]], [[Educational Institute of Scotland|EIS]], [[GMB (trade union)|GMB]] and UCU. Citing long-term real-terms declining pay, the unions submitted a pay claim seeking a 7.5 per cent pay increase or £1,500, whichever was greater; a £10 minimum wage to make all higher education institutions "[[living wage]]" employers; and gender pay equality by 2020.<ref name="HE_Pay_claim_submitted 2018">'[http://www.ucu.org.uk/media/9311/UCUBANHE29/pdf/HE_Pay_claim_submitted.pdf University and College Union Higher Education Branch Action Note]', UCUBAN/HE29 (21 March 2018).</ref> In April 2018, the [[Universities and Colleges Employers Association]] proposed a 1.7% pay increase for 2018-19, raising the offer to 2% (and 2.8% for the lowest paid) in May. These figures were both below inflation, which in March 2018 stood at 2.7%.<ref name="ReferenceA">Jack Grove, '[https://www.timeshighereducation.com/news/uk-university-staff-offered-17-cent-pay-rise-2018-19 UK university staff offered 1.7 per cent pay rise for 2018-19]', ''Times Higher Education'' (16 April 2018 ).</ref><ref>Ellie Bothwell, '[https://www.timeshighereducation.com/news/uk-university-staff-offered-2-cent-pay-rise UK university staff offered 2 per cent pay rise]', ''Times Higher Education'' (11 May 2018).</ref> The ballots commenced in September 2018, running alongside the ongoing pensions dispute.<ref name="Anna McKie 2018">Anna McKie, '[https://www.timeshighereducation.com/news/uk-university-staff-vote-strike-action-pay-dispute UK university staff to vote on strike action in pay dispute]', ''Times Higher Education'' (29 June 2018).</ref> Although the majority of Union members voting voted to take industrial action, however, the turnout only passed the 50% of members required by the [[Trade Union Act 2016]] at seven universities (alongside which three Northern Irish universities, unaffected by the legislation, also voted to strike).<ref name="ReferenceB">'[https://www.ucu.org.uk/article/9724/Trade-union-laws-frustrate-national-support-for-strike-action-on-pay Trade union laws frustrate national support for strike action on pay]' (22 October 2018).</ref>
==Negotiations regarding pension proposals==
===Prior to industrial action===
In July 2017, USS reported a technical deficit (i.e. a gap between the fund's assets and its liabilities) of £17.5 billion, reported as the largest [[UK pensions#Underfunding|such shortfall]] in the UK at that time.<ref name="Economist2017"/> USS's deficit evaluation was based on suggestions that although the fund's [[assets]] had grown (reaching £60 billion, a one-fifth increase on the previous year), its [[Liability (financial accounting)|liabilities]] had also grown (reaching £78 billion, a one-third increase over the previous year).<ref name="FT2017">{{cite web |url=https://www.ft.com/content/914d9cba-7232-11e7-aca6-c6bd07df1a3c |title=University pension fund deficit soars to £17.5bn |last=Gordon |first=Sarah |date=28 July 2017 |website=[[Financial Times]] |accessdate=29 July 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170729214315/https://www.ft.com/content/914d9cba-7232-11e7-aca6-c6bd07df1a3c |archivedate=29 July 2017 |df=}}</ref> Following negotiations regarding the calculation of the deficit, the USS Joint Negotiating Committee accepted a technical deficit of £6.1 billion in November 2017.
The key change proposed by UUK was to close USS's [[Defined benefit pension plan|defined benefit scheme]] (possibly temporarily), replacing it with a [[Defined contribution plan|defined contribution scheme]].<ref name="auto5">Ben Chu, '[www.independent.co.uk/voices/university-lecturers-strike-economics-pensions-a8227421.html If you look at the economics, it's completely reasonable for university lecturers to strike over pension changes]', ''The Independent'' (25 February 2018).</ref>
Specifically, the USS Joint Negotiating Committee therefore made the following proposals, to be introduced after 1 April 2019:<ref>'[https://web.archive.org/web/20180203011521/https://www.uss.co.uk/how-uss-is-run/valuation/2017-valuation-updates/proposed-changes-to-future-uss-benefits Proposed changes to future USS benefits]'.</ref>
* Closing of the defined benefits section of the scheme (though mentioning the possibility of reintroducing it), with all future benefits (apart from death in service and ill health retirement benefits) being transferred to the defined contribution scheme. * Contributions would remain 8% for members and 18% for employers (of which 13.25% contributes directly to pensions, the rest being used for management and running costs, etc.). * Members would be enabled to pay only 4% while still receiving the usual employer contribution, while the option of paying an extra 1%, matched by the employer, would be removed. * Members' 8% (or 4%) would include a contribution to partly finance death in service and ill health retirement benefits. The closure of defined benefits was presented as a red line by UCU, which argued in favour of finding ways to sustain defined benefits, or to introduce a [[collective defined contribution scheme]]<ref name="auto5"/><ref>Christine Berry, '[https://www.opendemocracy.net/neweconomics/uss-tip-iceberg-pensions-system-hot-mess/ USS is the tip of the iceberg. Our pensions system is a hot mess] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180316071735/https://www.opendemocracy.net/neweconomics/uss-tip-iceberg-pensions-system-hot-mess/ |date=16 March 2018 }}', ''OpenDemocracy'' (1 March 2018).</ref><ref name=":300">{{cite web |url=https://www.timeshighereducation.com/blog/uss-strike-social-media-has-collapsed-case-pension-cuts |title=USS strike: social media has collapsed the case for pension cuts |date=12 March 2018 |work=Times Higher Education (THE)|access-date=12 March 2018 |language=en |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180312125218/https://www.timeshighereducation.com/blog/uss-strike-social-media-has-collapsed-case-pension-cuts |archivedate=12 March 2018 |df=}}</ref><ref name=":1" /> (the primary legislation for which was introduced in the UK in 2015, but which had not as of March 2018 been advanced to secondary legislation).<ref>'[https://www.pensions-expert.com/DB-Derisking/UUK-and-UCU-strike-pensions-deal UUK and UCU strike pensions deal]', ''Pensions Expert'' (12 March 2018).</ref>
====Arguments for the changes==== USS argued that market conditions had simply proven less favourable than previous valuations had assumed, with the chief executive, Bill Galvin, arguing that 'the unavoidable fact is that market conditions have changed since 2014. Real interest rates have fallen since 2014, relative to inflation, and asset prices have soared ... We are now having to pay more – to get less in return – than we expected in the past'. Moreover, USS emphasised that its room for manoeuvre was constrained by [[the Pensions Regulator]].<ref>Bill Galvin, '[https://www.timeshighereducation.com/blog/uss-strike-we-cant-ignore-reality-our-deficit-says-pensions-boss USS strike: we can’t ignore reality of our deficit, says pensions boss] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180322143304/https://www.timeshighereducation.com/blog/uss-strike-we-cant-ignore-reality-our-deficit-says-pensions-boss |date=22 March 2018 }}', ''Times Higher Education'' (19 March 2018).</ref>
In theory, the deficit could have been resolved through higher contribution rates. However, UUK argued that defined benefit schemes were becoming prohibitively expensive.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/mar/12/striking-lecturer-slow-death-public-education |title=Why I'm a striking lecturer: I want to stop the slow death of public education {{!}} Becky Gardiner|last=Gardiner|first=Becky|date=12 March 2018|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=12 March 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180312110529/https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/mar/12/striking-lecturer-slow-death-public-education|archivedate=12 March 2018|df=}}</ref> They said they had a legal duty to put in place a credible plan to reduce the deficit by the summer of 2018. Otherwise, pension contributions from employers and staff would have to sharply increase, potentially resulting in redundancies and cuts to other areas of teaching, research and student support.<ref name=":5" /><ref name="auto6">Alistair Jarvis, '[https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/universities-uk-chief-alistair-jarvis-unions-pension-demands-will-cost-1bn-a-year-fb8v05jhs Universities UK chief Alistair Jarvis: union’s pension demands will cost £1bn a year]', ''The Sunday Times'' (18 March 2018), accessed from {{cite web|url=http://www.universitiesuk.ac.uk/blog/Pages/uss-pensions-update.aspx|title=Archived copy|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180320052813/http://www.universitiesuk.ac.uk/blog/Pages/uss-pensions-update.aspx|archivedate=20 March 2018|deadurl=no|accessdate=21 March 2018|df=}}.</ref> UUK stated the defined contributions proposal would compare well with private-sector competitors, with employer contributions double the private sector average.<ref name=":500" />
USS had a legal responsibility to satisfy the UK pensions regulator that the scheme was sound, and the regulator was requiring change.<ref name=":17" />
====Arguments against the changes==== UCU stated that UUK's proposal would "leave a typical lecturer almost £10,000 a year worse off in retirement than under the current set-up",<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/mar/05/university-pension-strike-listening |title=The university pension strike will only end when we're listened to {{!}} Sally Hunt|last=Hunt|first=Sally|date=5 March 2018|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=12 March 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180311132107/https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/mar/05/university-pension-strike-listening|archivedate=11 March 2018|df=}}</ref> with younger staff the worst affected, with some losing up to half their anticipated pensions.<ref name=":5" />
Critics of the changes offered the following main arguments against implementing the changes to the scheme promoted by UUK. * UUK's assessment of the health of the higher education sector after a 2015/16 report by [[Higher Education Funding Council for England|the Higher Education Funding Council for England (HEFCE)]] found the sector was financially sound.<ref name=":2" /><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.hefce.ac.uk/analysis/HEinEngland/finhealth/ |title=Financial health overview - Higher Education Funding Council for England |last=England |first=Higher Education Funding Council for |website=www.hefce.ac.uk |language=en|access-date=12 March 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180312105935/http://www.hefce.ac.uk/analysis/HEinEngland/finhealth/ |archivedate=12 March 2018 |df=}}</ref> Independent analyses undertaken by [[University of Warwick]] economist Dennis Leech and [[University College London|UCL]] academic Sean Wallis argued that UUK used a "flawed valuation model".<ref name=":3"/> * The proposed USS changes were shaped by the demand of the UK pensions regulator that USS should be made less risky to employers than USS's actuaries had wished. It was argued, however, that in view of the exceptional economic circumstances associated with the Bank of England's [[quantitative easing]] from 2009, the regulator was placing unrealistic expectations on UK pensions nationally.<ref name=":17">David Bailey and John Clancy, '[https://www.timeshighereducation.com/blog/uss-strike-regulator-blame-pensions-crisis USS strike: regulator is to blame for pensions crisis]', ''Times Higher Education'' (13 March 2013).</ref><ref name="timeshighereducation.com"/> * Concern also grew, on the basis of research by [[Michael Otsuka]] from the [[London School of Economics]], that UUK's negotiating position was disproportionately influenced by the views of Oxford and Cambridge Universities, whose constituent colleges made separate submissions to consultations.<ref name="auto7">Richard Adams, '[https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2018/feb/21/universities-strike-blamed-on-vote-by-oxbridge-colleges Universities strike blamed on vote by Oxbridge colleges] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180227001146/https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2018/feb/21/universities-strike-blamed-on-vote-by-oxbridge-colleges |date=27 February 2018 }}', ''The Guardian'' (21 February 2018).</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/education/education-news/oxbridge-universities-higher-education-strike-pensions-cuts-more-say-ucu-a8223011.html |title=Oxbridge universities 'given greater say than other institutions' on pensions cuts driving higher education strike |last=Baynes |first=Chris |date=22 February 2018 |work=The Independent|access-date=18 March 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180304081549/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/education/education-news/oxbridge-universities-higher-education-strike-pensions-cuts-more-say-ucu-a8223011.html|archive-date=4 March 2018|dead-url=}}</ref><ref name=":300" /> * Current employees were annually paying £2.1bn into the USS fund, while it was annually paying out £1.8bn to pensioners. To cover the current annual cost of pensions from investment returns, the fund required a net annual return of 3%.<ref>Anthony Hesketh, '[https://www.theguardian.com/higher-education-network/2018/feb/22/the-solution-to-university-pensions-better-fund-managers The solution to university pensions? Better fund managers] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180227003931/https://www.theguardian.com/higher-education-network/2018/feb/22/the-solution-to-university-pensions-better-fund-managers |date=27 February 2018 }}', ''The Guardian'', 22 February 2018.</ref> One of the assumptions used in the July 2017 valuation was that the fund would stop accepting contributions — the sort of situation that would normally arise if the companies in a pension scheme went bust, which was an unlikely real-world situation for the UK higher education sector.<ref name="LeechBlog">{{Cite web |url=https://blogs.warwick.ac.uk/dennisleech/entry/is_the_uss_1_2/ |title=Is the USS really in crisis?, 23/11/17, Dennis Leech's blog |website=blogs.warwick.ac.uk|access-date=6 February 2018}}</ref> USS's analyses showed that, assuming the most likely circumstances rather than the most challenging circumstances (technically referred to as the "best estimate"), the pension scheme was sustainable in the long-term. In contrast to technical deficits based on stringently conservative assumptions, this more probable valuation showed the fund in credit by £8.3 billion.<ref name="LeechBlog" /> * At the inception of USS, employer contributions were 16% of salary, rising to 18.55% in 1983. However, from January 1997 to September 2009 they were decreased to 14% (before rising to 16% from October 2009 to 2016 and 18% thereafter). It was suggested that staff were bearing the consequences of an earlier lack of investment by employers.<ref name="Logan1985"/><ref name="Cooper2014">Susan Cooper, '[https://users.physics.ox.ac.uk/~scooper/USS/2014-11%20Pensions.pdf A Pensions Proposal: Constant Contributions] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180228041225/https://users.physics.ox.ac.uk/~scooper/USS/2014-11%20Pensions.pdf |date=28 February 2018 }}' (p. 1).</ref>
===UCU ballots for industrial action (29 January)=== On 29 January, UCU announced that 88% of UCU members had voted to back strike action and 93% backed action short of a strike.<ref name="auto8">{{Cite web |url=https://www.ucu.org.uk/article/9242/UCU-announces-14-strike-dates-at-61-universities-in-pensions-row |title=UCU announces 14 strike dates at 61 universities in pensions row |website=www.ucu.org.uk |language=en-gb|access-date=6 February 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180202232646/https://www.ucu.org.uk/article/9242/UCU-announces-14-strike-dates-at-61-universities-in-pensions-row |archivedate=2 February 2018 |df=}}</ref> The turnout was 58%,<ref name=":0" /> meeting the 50% minimum set by the [[Trade Union Act 2016]].
Shortly after, on 13 February, the trade union [[UNISON]], many of whose members in the Higher Education sector were also USS members, began a consultative ballot on striking alongside UCU.<ref>'[https://www.unison.org.uk/news/article/2018/02/uss-letter/ HE members to be consulted over proposed pension changes]' (13 February 2019).</ref> On 20 February, UNISON wrote to vice-chancellors in support of UCU's position.<ref>'[https://www.unison.org.uk/news/article/2018/02/uss-letter/ UNISON writes to vice chancellors over university pensions dispute]' (20 February 2018).</ref>
===Strike action commences (23 February) and new negotiations follow=== [[File:International Women's Day and Leeds UCU signs, 2018.jpg|thumb|International Women's Day and Leeds UCU signs, 2018]] Strikes commenced on 23 February, whereupon UUK agreed to meet UCU for further negotiations on 27 February. Leaked emails suggested they would not negotiate on UCU's key issue, retaining defined benefits.<ref>Camilla Turner, '[{{cite web |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/education/2018/02/24/lecturers-poised-escalate-disruption-leaked-letter-reveals-university/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=16 March 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180226205324/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/education/2018/02/24/lecturers-poised-escalate-disruption-leaked-letter-reveals-university/ |archivedate=26 February 2018 |df=}} Lecturers' strike: universities refusing to bow on pension reforms, leaked letter reveals', ''The Sunday Telegraph'' (24 February 2018).</ref> The meeting led to an agreement to undergo conciliation through [[Acas]], the UK's national industrial dispute conciliation body. UCU tabled and published a set of proposals which it argued was consistent with the majority of UUK members' positions in USS's earlier consultation, but strikes were not called off.<ref>Richard Adams and Emily Hawkins, '[https://www.theguardian.com/education/2018/feb/27/university-staff-pension-dispute-moves-to-acas University staff pension dispute moves to Acas] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180316183540/https://www.theguardian.com/education/2018/feb/27/university-staff-pension-dispute-moves-to-acas |date=16 March 2018 }}', ''The Guardian'' (27 February 2018).</ref><ref>Camilla Turner, '[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/education/2018/02/27/lecturers-university-leaders-enlist-conciliation-service-acas/ Lecturers and university leaders enlist conciliation service Acas but strikes are set to continue ] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180304115142/https://www.telegraph.co.uk/education/2018/02/27/lecturers-university-leaders-enlist-conciliation-service-acas/ |date=4 March 2018 }}', ''The Telegraph'' (27 February 2018).</ref><ref>'[https://www.ucu.org.uk/article/9364/Further-talks-agreed-in-universities-pensions-dispute Further talks agreed in universities pensions dispute] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180228201401/https://www.ucu.org.uk/article/9364/Further-talks-agreed-in-universities-pensions-dispute |date=28 February 2018 }}' (27 February 2018).</ref>
A spokesperson for Universities UK said: "Both sides are currently engaged in serious and constructive talks at [[Acas]]. We are committed to seeking a viable, affordable and mutually acceptable solution to the current challenges facing USS pensions."<ref name=":4">{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/education-43337090|title=Fresh strikes could hit university exams|date=8 March 2018|work=BBC News|language=en-GB|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180311202906/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/education-43337090|archivedate=11 March 2018|deadurl=no|access-date=12 March 2018|df=}}</ref>
===UCU's proposal (27 February)===
UCU tabled an alternative proposal at the first round of talks with UUK which UCU stated would involve universities accepting some increased risk and small increased contributions from employers and scheme members.<ref name=":1" /> UUK's response was that they would need time to cost the union's proposal which it feared would require "very substantial increases in contributions". However, some vice-chancellors voiced support for UCU's plan.<ref name=":1" />
UCU's proposal, along with suggestions for longer-term strategies, was:<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.ucu.org.uk/article/9364/Further-talks-agreed-in-universities-pensions-dispute |title='Further talks agreed in universities pensions dispute' (27 February 2018) |access-date=28 February 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180228201401/https://www.ucu.org.uk/article/9364/Further-talks-agreed-in-universities-pensions-dispute |archive-date=28 February 2018 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
* Universities should accept a slightly riskier but probably more lucrative investment strategy, leading to a deficit of £5.1bn rather than £6.1bn, a level accepted by the majority of institutions when it was proposed by USS in September 2017. * Retaining defined benefits on salaries up to £55,550. * Reducing the annual accrual rate reduced from 1/75th to 1/80th. * Increasing contributions by 2.7% for employers and 1.4% for members (i.e. 4.1% split 65/35 between employers and employees). The parties held inconclusive talks on 5 March, scheduling the next talks for 7 March.<ref name=":4" /> However, a bizarre Twitter spasm from UUK on the night of 5 March insisted that the group was available for talks on 6 March, and this led to talks at noon on 6 March.<ref>Judith Burns, '[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/education-43295334 University strike talks resume after Twitter skirmishes] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180312192658/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/education-43295334 |date=12 March 2018 }}', ''BBC News'' (6 March 2018).</ref> Talks continued on 7 March, inconclusively. On 8 March, UCU's Higher Education Committee agreed that it would call further strikes if necessary after the Easter vacation, between April and June.<ref>Robert Wright, '[https://www.ft.com/content/57a6f7b6-22fb-11e8-ae48-60d3531b7d11 UK universities could be hit by new strikes amid pension dispute] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180309054353/https://www.ft.com/content/57a6f7b6-22fb-11e8-ae48-60d3531b7d11 |date=9 March 2018 }}', ''Financial Times'' (8 March 2018).</ref>
===Joint UUK and UCU proposal (12 March)=== [[File:Placard from March 13 2018 UCU protest, Leeds.jpg|thumb|Placard from 13 March 2018 UCU protest, Leeds.]] On the evening of Monday 12 March UCU and UUK issued a joint agreement, arrived at through ACAS, to be put to their respective members.<ref name=":7">{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/education-43380857 |title=Deal offered in university pensions row |last=Coughlan |first=Sean |date=13 March 2018 |work=BBC News|access-date=13 March 2018 |language=en-GB |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180313001707/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/education-43380857 |archivedate=13 March 2018 |df=}}</ref>
The agreement was specifically for a three-year "transitional benefit arrangement" lasting from 1 April 2019, maintaining defined benefits up to a salary threshold of £42,000, reducing the accrual rate to 1/85, but raising contributions to 19.3% of salaries for employers and 8.7% for members. The next valuation was to be informed by an "independent expert group", 'aiming to promote greater transparency and understanding' of the methodologies, assumptions, and viability of the scheme. Indexation and revaluation was to be measured using CPI and capped at up to 2.5% p.a. (meaning that if inflation, measured by CPI, rose above 2.5%, the pension would lose value in real terms). UCU was to suspend industrial action and "encourage" branches to re-schedule any classes disrupted by the strike. The agreement stated that "there is commitment between both sides to engage in meaningful discussions as soon as possible to explore risk sharing alternatives for the future from 2020, in particular Collective Defined Contributions".<ref>University and College Union and Universities UK, '[https://www.ucu.org.uk/media/9300/Agreement-reached-between-UCU-and-UUK-under-the-auspices-of-ACAS/pdf/UCU_UUK_agreement_at_ACAS_12_March_Final.pdf Agreement reached between UCU and UUK under the auspices of ACAS] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180312190956/https://www.ucu.org.uk/media/9300/Agreement-reached-between-UCU-and-UUK-under-the-auspices-of-ACAS/pdf/UCU_UUK_agreement_at_ACAS_12_March_Final.pdf |date=12 March 2018 }}' (12 March 2018).</ref><ref name=":8">{{Cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/education/2018/mar/13/striking-university-staff-irate-over-pensions-deal-ucu |title=University strikes to continue after staff reject pension offer |last=Weale |first=Sally |date=13 March 2018 |website=the Guardian |language=en|access-date=14 March 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180313190115/https://www.theguardian.com/education/2018/mar/13/striking-university-staff-irate-over-pensions-deal-ucu |archivedate=13 March 2018 |df=}}</ref><ref name=":7" />
Vice-chancellors were to inform UUK whether they would back this deal by the end of day on Wednesday 14 March while UCU representatives consulted with their members on whether to reject the deal or not the next day.<ref name=":7" />
===Acas agreement withdrawn by UCU (13 March)=== [[File:Picket at University of Edinburgh.jpg|alt=UCU meeting at University of Edinburgh|thumb|293x293px|UCU meeting at the [[University of Edinburgh]]]] Local branch meetings were held on Tuesday 13 March to consider the ACAS agreement. These meetings informed a meeting of elected and branch representatives the same day. This agreement was rejected by UCU's membership on the grounds that it failed to address members' concerns.<ref>'[https://www.ucu.org.uk/article/9401/University-strikes-remain-on-as-UCU-rejects-proposals?list=1676 University strikes remain on as UCU rejects proposals] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180313164953/https://www.ucu.org.uk/article/9401/University-strikes-remain-on-as-UCU-rejects-proposals?list=1676 |date=13 March 2018 }}' (13 March 2018).</ref><ref>Sean Coughlan, '[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/education-43388912 University strikers reject pension deal] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180316130245/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/education-43388912 |date=16 March 2018 }}', ''BBC News'' (13 March 2018).</ref><ref name=":8" /><ref name=":9">{{Cite web |url=https://www.ucu.org.uk/article/9401/University-strikes-remain-on-as-UCU-rejects-proposals?list=1676 |title=University strikes remain on as UCU rejects proposals |website=www.ucu.org.uk |language=en-gb|access-date=14 March 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180313164953/https://www.ucu.org.uk/article/9401/University-strikes-remain-on-as-UCU-rejects-proposals?list=1676 |archivedate=13 March 2018 |df=}}</ref> Many UCU members used the Twitter hashtag #NoCapitulation to express their disapproval of the agreement,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/education/2018/mar/13/striking-university-staff-irate-over-pensions-deal-ucu |title=University strikes to continue after staff reject pension offer |last=Weale |first=Sally |date=13 March 2018 |work=The Guardian|access-date=18 March 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180318013105/https://www.theguardian.com/education/2018/mar/13/striking-university-staff-irate-over-pensions-deal-ucu|archive-date=18 March 2018|dead-url=}}</ref> helping to co-ordinate a strong response to the proposals.<ref name="auto9">Nicole Kobie, '[https://www.wired.co.uk/article/no-capitulation-uk-university-pension-protest-twitter #NoCapitulation: How one hashtag saved the UK university strike] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180321050532/http://www.wired.co.uk/article/no-capitulation-uk-university-pension-protest-twitter |date=21 March 2018 }}', ''Wired'' (18 March 2018).</ref><ref name=":10">{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/education-43388912|title=University strikers reject pension deal|last=Coughlan|first=Sean|date=13 March 2018|work=BBC News|language=en-GB|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180313200220/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/education-43388912|archivedate=13 March 2018|deadurl=no|access-date=14 March 2018|df=}}</ref>
UCU general secretary [[Sally Hunt]] said that preparations for strikes during the exam period would be made, while urgently seeking further talks.<ref name=":9" /><ref>See further '[https://www.ucu.org.uk/article/9404/How-we-got-to-yesterday-and-whats-next How we got to yesterday and what's next]' (14 March 2018).</ref>
A UUK spokesperson said: <blockquote>It is hugely disappointing that students' education will be further disrupted through continued strike action. We have engaged extensively with UCU negotiators to find a mutually acceptable way forward.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.universitiesuk.ac.uk/news/Pages/UCU-rejects-proposals-jointly-agreed-at-ACAS.aspx |title=UCU rejects proposals jointly agreed at ACAS |website=www.universitiesuk.ac.uk |language=en-GB |access-date=14 March 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180315133330/http://www.universitiesuk.ac.uk/news/Pages/UCU-rejects-proposals-jointly-agreed-at-ACAS.aspx |archivedate=15 March 2018 |df=dmy-all }}</ref></blockquote> In some places, the decision was followed the next day by rallies.<ref name="auto10">Kristian Johnson, '[https://www.leeds-live.co.uk/news/leeds-news/five-things-learned-latest-ucu-14410973 Five things we learned from the latest UCU rally through Leeds city centre] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180318060411/https://www.leeds-live.co.uk/news/leeds-news/five-things-learned-latest-ucu-14410973 |date=18 March 2018 }}', ''LeedsLive'' (14 March 2018).</ref>
===Developments 14–23 March===
As of 14 March, UUK's consultation with its members remained ongoing.<ref>'[http://www.universitiesuk.ac.uk/news/Pages/planning-more-talks-with-UCU.aspx Universities UK planning more talks with UCU to end pensions dispute] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180316023228/http://www.universitiesuk.ac.uk/news/Pages/planning-more-talks-with-UCU.aspx |date=16 March 2018 }}' (14 March 2018).</ref>
A statutory 64-day consultation by USS on pension changes had been due to commence on 19 March, but as of 15 March, USS were declaring an unspecified delay to the commencement of consultations.<ref>'[https://www.ussconsultation2018.co.uk/members/info Employer consultation in relation to proposed changes to Universities Superannuation Scheme ] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180316151911/https://www.ussconsultation2018.co.uk/members/info |date=16 March 2018 }}' (accessed 15 March 2018).</ref>
On 16 March, UCU called on members employed as external examiners to resign until the dispute was resolved.<ref>Chris Havergal, '[https://www.timeshighereducation.com/news/call-external-examiners-quit-uk-pensions-dispute Call for external examiners to quit in UK pensions dispute] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180316214248/https://www.timeshighereducation.com/news/call-external-examiners-quit-uk-pensions-dispute |date=16 March 2018 }}', ''Times Higher Education'' (16 March 2018).</ref> By 23 March over 600 resignations had occurred.<ref name="auto12">Sophie Inge, '[https://www.timeshighereducation.com/news/hundreds-external-examiners-resign-uk-pensions-dispute Hundreds of external examiners resign in UK pensions dispute]', ''Times Higher Education'' (23 March 2018).</ref>
On 18 March, UUK announced that it would convene an "independent panel", featuring an independent chair and involving academics and pension professionals, to "consider issues of methodology, assumptions and monitoring, aiming to promote greater transparency and understanding of the USS valuation". The panel would invite UCU "to play a full role in providing evidence to the panel" and would also liaise with USS and the pensions regulator.<ref>'[https://www.universitiesuk.ac.uk/news/Pages/Panel-of-independent-experts-to-review-processes-for-arriving-at-pension-deficit.aspx Panel of independent experts to review processes for arriving at pension deficit]' (18 March 2018).</ref><ref name="auto6"/> UCU's response was that "UCU will of course look at any proposals UUK makes but our members have made it quite clear that what is needed is a much improved offer".<ref>'[https://www.ucu.org.uk/article/9412/UCU-responds-to-UUK-valuation-review UCU responds to UUK valuation review]' (18 March 2018).</ref>
On 22 March, UCU sanctioned fourteen further strike days to fall in the April to June 2018 exam period should the talks fail to come to a resolution.<ref name=":4" />
On 23 March, UNISON announced that its consultative ballot of its USS members had returned 91% support for industrial action, and that it would begin a formal ballot for strike action in April.<ref>'[https://www.unison.org.uk/news/2018/03/he-pension/ University members asked to strike to defend USS pension scheme]' (23 March 2018).</ref><ref>Talya Misiri, '[https://www.pensionsage.com/pa/Enough-is-enough-Unison-urges-USS-members-to-join-industrial-action.php ‘Enough is enough’ Unison urges USS members to join industrial action]', ''PensionsAge'' (23 March 2018).</ref><ref>'[https://morningstaronline.co.uk/article/unison-strike-ballot-over-university-pensions Unison strike ballot over university pensions]', ''Morning Star'' (24 March 2018).</ref>
===UUK makes a new offer (23 March)===
On 23 March, UCU announced a new offer from UUK. This proposed the creation of a formal "Joint Expert Panel" to reconsider how valuations should be undertaken, leaving open the possibility of maintaining the status quo not only for the statutory period up to April 2019, but possibly beyond. The panel would <blockquote>take into account the unique nature of the HE sector, inter-generational fairness and equality considerations, the need to strike a fair balance between ensuring stability and risk. Recognising that staff highly value Defined Benefit provision, the work of the group will reflect the clear wish of staff to have a guaranteed pension comparable with current provision whilst meeting the affordability challenges for all parties, within the current regulatory framework.<ref>'[https://www.ucu.org.uk/article/9422/New-offer-sent-to-UCU-members-in-USS-pensions-dispute?list=1676 New offer sent to UCU members in USS pensions dispute]' (23 March 2018).</ref></blockquote> The ''Financial Times'' noted that this would be "a far more comprehensive review of the current structure and valuation of the Universities Superannuation Scheme" than previously considered, but also noted that "the new agreement avoids any mention of increases in contributions by either employers or employees to plug the hole in the scheme".<ref name="ft.com">{{cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/5d991390-2ebb-11e8-a34a-7e7563b0b0f4|title=Subscribe to read|website=Financial Times}}</ref> UCU was due to consult members' representatives at a formal meeting on 28 March.<ref name="ft.com"/><ref>Max Jenner, '[https://oxfordstudent.com/2018/03/23/uuk-tables-new-proposal-for-ucu/ NewsUUK tables new proposal for UCU]', ''Oxford Student'' (23 March 2018).</ref>
Meanwhile, on 26 March, the UK's Joint Negotiating Committee for Higher Education Staff began its round of negotiations for pay in the sector for 2018/19, with unions demanding a large pay uplift.<ref name="HE_Pay_claim_submitted 2018"/><ref name="ReferenceA"/>
===New strike dates announced as UCU members balloted on proposal (28 March)=== UCU announced that members would be electronically balloted on the new offer in April to decide on the proposal for the Joint Expert Panel.<ref name=":15">{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/education/2018/mar/28/uk-university-staff-to-vote-on-latest-pensions-offer|title=UK university staff to vote on latest pensions offer|last=Adams|first=Richard|date=2018-03-28|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-03-28}}</ref> UUK pledged to maintain the current contributions and retirement benefits until at least April 2019 while the review by the panel of experts took place.<ref name=":15" />
At the same time, UCU gave formal notice of a five-day strike action, aimed at disrupting the exams and assessments period, at some universities for 16 April to 20 April 2018, potentially to be called off if there was progress in the negotiations.<ref name=":15" /> 13 universities including Manchester, Cardiff, Oxford, St Andrews, Leeds and Southampton would be affected by this next round of strikes with the prospect of industrial action at the other 52 universities to take place later in April and continuing into July if no agreement was reached.<ref name=":15" /><ref name=":14" /> However, staff would not take part in additional strike action if UCU members vote to accept the UUK proposal.<ref name=":14" />
As of 28 March, nearly 700 external examiners had recorded their resignations in a UCU document.<ref name=":14" /> ''The Guardian'' reported that "students at the end of their courses could find themselves unable to graduate if crucial exams cannot be invigilated, marked or assessed" as a worst-case scenario.<ref name=":15" />
Debate followed among UCU members as to whether to accept the proposals or not.<ref>Steven Parfitt, '[https://www.jacobinmag.com/2018/03/universities-uk-strike-contract-vote-education Deal or No Deal?]', ''Jacobin'' (3 March 2018).</ref> As of 4 April, some branches had decided to recommend that their members reject the proposals as they stood,<ref>Richard Adams, '[https://www.theguardian.com/education/2018/apr/04/university-staff-vote-on-pensions-offer-without-a-deal-in-sight University staff vote on pensions offer – without a deal in sight]', ''The Guardian'' (4 April 2018).</ref><ref>Sophie Inge, '[https://www.timeshighereducation.com/news/under-pressure-ucu-leader-urges-members-accept-pensions-deal Under-pressure UCU leader urges members to accept pensions deal]', ''Times Higher Education'' (4 April 2018).</ref> and prominent discontent with the proposals continued to be registered in the run-up to the ballot closing.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.timeshighereducation.com/news/union-unrest-opens-new-front-uk-university-pensions-dispute|title=Union unrest opens new front in UK university pensions dispute|date=2018-04-09|work=Times Higher Education (THE)|access-date=2018-04-20|language=en}}</ref>
===UCU accepts UUK proposal (13 April) and Joint Expert Panel is formed===
The result of the ballot was the UCU members accepted UUK proposal. Industrial action was suspended and the impending strikes of 16 April were called off.<ref>'[https://www.ucu.org.uk/article/9438/Members-vote-to-accept-employers-latest-offer Members vote to accept employers' latest offer]' (13 April 2018).</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.universitiesuk.ac.uk/news/Pages/ballot-result-on-joint-expert-panel.aspx|title=Ballot result on Joint Expert Panel|website=www.universitiesuk.ac.uk|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-04-17}}</ref><ref>Chris Havergal, '[https://www.timeshighereducation.com/news/strikes-suspended-union-members-vote-end-pensions-dispute Strikes suspended as union members vote to end pensions dispute]', ''Times Higher Education'' (13 April 2018).</ref>
{| class="wikitable" |+ |Total balloted |53,415 |- |Total votes cast |33,973 |- |Total number valid votes |33,913 |- |Turnout |63.5% |- |Yes to accept the UUK offer |21,683 (64%) |- |No to reject the UUK offer |12,230 (36%) |} On 18 April, UCU confirmed that it was ending its call for external examiners to stand down.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ucu.org.uk/article/9441/Latest-developments|title=Latest developments|website=www.ucu.org.uk|language=en-gb|access-date=2018-04-19}}</ref> Commentary suggested that scrutiny of the pension negotiations by the union membership was nonetheless ongoing.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/apr/16/university-pensions-strikes-union-campaign|title=Universities ending the strikes is not a climbdown – the fight goes on {{!}} Des Freedman|last=Freedman|first=Des|date=2018-04-16|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-04-20}}</ref>
On 18 May, UUK and UCU announced that the Joint Expert Panel would be chaired by Joanne Segars.<ref>'[https://www.universitiesuk.ac.uk/news/Pages/UCU-and-UUK-announce-appointment-of-Chair-for-USS-Joint-Expert-Panel.aspx UCU and UUK announce appointment of Chair for USS Joint Expert Panel]', 18 May 2018.</ref><ref>[https://www.ucu.org.uk/article/9490/UCU-and-UUK-announce-appointment-of-Chair-for-USS-Joint-Expert-Panel UCU and UUK announce appointment of Chair for USS Joint Expert Panel]' (18 May 2018).</ref> On 21 May UCU announced three nominations to the panel.<ref>'[https://www.ucu.org.uk/article/9493/UCU-announces-nominations-to-USS-joint-expert-panel= UCU announces nominations to USS joint expert pane]' (221 May 201).</ref> Other members were later determined as Ronnie Bowie, Sally Bridgeland, and Chris Curry (appointed by UUK) and Catherine Donnelly, Saul Jacka, and Deborah Mabbett (appointed by UCU).<ref>The Joint Expert Panel on the Universities Superannuation Scheme commissioned by the University and College Union and Universities UK, '[https://web.archive.org/web/20180913161622/http://www.ussjep.org.uk/files/2018/09/report-of-the-joint-expert-panel.pdf Report of the Joint Expert Panel]' (September 2018), pp. 70-71.</ref> The Joint Expert Panel was scheduled to report in September.<ref name=":16">{{Cite news|url=https://www.timeshighereducation.com/news/uss-announces-increases-higher-education-pension-contributions|title=USS announces increases in higher education pension contributions|last=|first=|date=|work=|access-date=}}</ref>
On 1–3 June, a tumultuous UCU congress included calls for the general secretary, Sally Hunt, to resign over what was perceived to be undemocratic practice within the Union's prosecution of the dispute. Much of the congress's proceedings had to be aborted, and a new congress was proposed for the future.<ref>Chris Havergal, '[https://www.timeshighereducation.com/news/sally-hunt-clings-ucu-leader-congress-curtailed Sally Hunt clings on as UCU leader as congress curtailed]', ''Times Higher Education'' (1 June 2018).</ref> (On October 18, a recalled congress saw the withdrawal of motions to call for resignation, but a motion of censure was passed complaining at a lack of transparency and accountability in Hunt's representation of UCU members during the dispute.<ref>Jack Grove, '[https://www.timeshighereducation.com/news/ucus-sally-hunt-censured-over-handling-pensions-strike UCU’s Sally Hunt censured over handling of pensions strike]', ''Times Higher Education'' (18 October 2018).</ref>)
On 6 June, UCU commenced a consultative ballot to determine whether to conduct a formal ballot for industrial action in relation to the UK Joint Negotiating Committee for Higher Education Staff's negotiations over 2018-19 pay. The ballot closed on 27 June 2018, with 82% of participating members voting to reject the offer from the University and Colleges Employers’ Association of a minimum pay rise of 2 per cent, rising to 2.8 per cent for the lowest paid.<ref name="Anna McKie 2018"/> UCU formally declared a trade dispute on 24 July 2018.<ref name="HE national negotiations 2018-19">'[https://web.archive.org/web/20180911184449/https://www.ucu.org.uk/he2018?utm_source=lyr-ucu-members&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=members&utm_term=he-full-jnches&utm_content=Pay+and+equality+ballot+now+open HE national negotiations 2018-19]' (accessed 11 September 2018).</ref>
=== USS plans contribution increases (25 July) === While the Joint Expert Panel deliberated, USS announced that, given that the legal deadline for addressing the fund's deficit had passed, it would, in accordance with statutory procedure, act already to raise both staff and employer contributions, following a statutory consultation period, to maintain the scheme's benefits. The proposed rises (as a percentage of salary) were to be phased in over a year: {| class="wikitable" |+ ! !Staff contributions !Employer contributions |- |status quo |8% |18% |- |April 2019 |8.8% |19.5% |- |October 2019 |10.4% |22.5% |- |April 2020 |11.7% |24.9% |} These plans were announced against a backdrop of USS's annual report calculations of the deficit falling, due to changing assumptions about factors such as returns on corporate bonds and mortality. On different measures, the 2018 annual report showed a 2014 deficit of 12.6bn falling to a 2018 deficit of 12.1bn; or a £17.5bn deficit falling to £8.4 billion deficit.<ref name=":16" />
On 21 August, UCU served statutory notice of its intention to ballot members for industrial action regarding the 2018-19 national pay dispute. The ballot opened on 30 August.<ref name="HE national negotiations 2018-19"/>
=== Joint Expert Panel releases first report (13 September) === On 13 September, the Joint Expert Panel that had been convened to re-examine the valuation of the USS scheme issued its first report.<ref>The Joint Expert Panel on the Universities Superannuation Scheme commissioned by the University and College Union and Universities UK, '[https://web.archive.org/web/20180913161622/http://www.ussjep.org.uk/files/2018/09/report-of-the-joint-expert-panel.pdf Report of the Joint Expert Panel]' (September 2018).</ref><ref name="ucu.org.uk"/> The Panel's press release recommended a number of adjustments to the methodology and data used in the 2017 valuation of the USS scheme, and stated that "it is the Panel’s belief, based on independent actuarial analysis, that the full implementation of these adjustments could mean total required contributions estimated at 29.2% to fund current benefits [...] This compares to the current rate of 26% (18% of salary paid by employers, 8% by employees) and the rate of 36.6% from April 2020 which is proposed by USS, based on the valuation as it stands".<ref>'[https://web.archive.org/web/20180913141628/http://www.ussjep.org.uk/report-of-the-joint-expert-panel/ USS Joint Expert Panel]' (13 September 2018).</ref> It was suggested that this proposal might entail raising employees' contributions to 9.1% of salary, and employers' by 2.1%, taking their contribution to 20.1%.<ref>Jack Grove, '[https://www.timeshighereducation.com/news/pay-extra-1-salary-save-uss-pension-benefits-says-panel Pay extra 1% of salary to save USS pension benefits, says panel]', ''Times Higher Education'' (13 September 2018).</ref>
On October 15, Sam Marsh, of the University of Sheffield, reported in detail on his own analysis of data obtained from USS after a long period of requesting the information. He found that the methodologies by which USS's 'test 1' measures the pension scheme's viability were flawed, and that by maintaining previous investment strategies, USS would have the surplus it would require to meet its future liabilities. UUK asked the USS trustee to investigate Marsh's arguments.<ref>Josephine Cumbo, '[https://www.ft.com/content/3778c62c-d142-11e8-a9f2-7574db66bcd5 University pension fund accused of exaggerating shortfall]', ''The Financial Times'' (16 October 2018).</ref><ref>Sam Marsh, '[https://medium.com/ussbriefs/a-flawed-valuation-the-laypersons-guide-to-my-findings-on-uss-s-test-1-b9e0c53f5d67 A flawed valuation: the layperson’s guide to my findings on USS’s ‘Test 1’]' (15 October 2018).</ref><ref>Felicity Callard, Jo Grady, Nick Hardy, Jaya John John, Nicky Priaulx, and Ruth Stirton, '[https://medium.com/ussbriefs/there-must-be-something-missing-here-sam-marsh-exposes-new-problems-in-the-uss-valuation-351c90b1ab30 Sam Marsh exposes new problems in the USS valuation', ''USSbriefs'', 59 (16 October 2018).]</ref> Marsh's commentary had also attracted prominent support from [[Michael Otsuka]].<ref>Michael Otsuka, '[https://web.archive.org/web/20181018204618/https://medium.com/@mikeotsuka/usss-valuation-rests-on-a-large-and-demonstrable-mistake-691103c94ca6 USS’s valuation rests on a large and demonstrable mistake]' (13 October 2018).</ref> USS defended its position the next day, accepting that Marsh's reanalysis was 'not wrong in isolation', but arguing that de-risking was necessary anyway.<ref>'[https://web.archive.org/web/20181019200234/https://www.uss.co.uk/how-uss-is-run/valuation/2017-valuation-updates/claims-of-a-large-and-demonstable-error Claims of a ‘large and demonstrable error’ in the valuation]', (16 October 2018).</ref><ref>Jack Grove, '[https://www.timeshighereducation.com/news/universities-superannuation-scheme-rejects-valuation-error-claim Universities Superannuation Scheme rejects valuation error claim]', ''Times Higher Education'' (17 October 2018).</ref>
On October 22, UCU announced the results of the ballot on striking over pay. Although the majority of Union members who voted elected to take industrial action, the turnout only passed the 50% of members required by the [[Trade Union Act 2016]] at seven universities (alongside which three Northern Irish universities, unaffected by the legislation, also voted to strike).<ref name="ReferenceB"/> Likewise, on October 29, Unison reported that although a majority of voting members had supported strike action, the vote was frustrated by insufficient turnout.<ref>'[https://web.archive.org/web/20181031130100/https://www.unison.org.uk/news/article/2018/10/he-ballot-result/ Higher education ballot result]' (29 October 2018).</ref>
==Responses to the strikes== [[File:UCU Higher Education Strike rally.jpg|alt=UCU Higher Education Strike rally, George Square, Glasgow.|thumb|Crowds gather at a UCU strike rally in George Square, Glasgow.]]
=== Changes in UK law === The strike brought to the attention of unions and the UK government a potential ambiguity in UK legislation: migrant workers on [[Visa policy of the United Kingdom|Tier 2 and 5 visas]] have an annual 20-day limit on unpaid absence from work. As some universities had seen local strike action during 2017-18 in addition to the 14 days of national strike action, fears arose that staff members who were on strike for more than 20 days in a year might have their visas revoked, and that this might in turn impinge on their legal rights to take industrial action.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.timeshighereducation.com/opinion/curtailing-overseas-scholars-right-strike-undermines-their-academic-citizenship|title=Curtailing overseas scholars’ right to strike undermines their academic citizenship|last=|first=|date=|work=|access-date=}}</ref> On 12 July, the [[Home Secretary|home secretary]] [[Sajid Javid]] declared that it was "not the government’s policy to prevent migrant workers from engaging in legal strike action" and that he would introduce changes to the rules and guidelines on immigration to be explicit that strike action did not count as "unpaid absence".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.timeshighereducation.com/news/javid-foreign-staff-can-strike-without-risking-right-remain|title=Javid: foreign staff can strike without risking right to remain|last=|first=|date=|work=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.parliament.uk/business/publications/written-questions-answers-statements/written-statement/Commons/2018-07-12/HCWS848|title=Immigration:Written statement - HCWS848|last=Javid|first=Sajid|date=12 July 2018|website=parliament.uk|access-date=}}</ref>
===Staff=== [[File:Dinosaur of Solidarity Lino Print.jpg|thumb|Dinosaur of Solidarity lino print, alluding to the presence of a dinosaur on Southampton UCU's picket lines.]] In the ballot for the strike, UCU achieved an unusually high turnout and strong support for industrial action, and membership grew by about 15,000 between the beginning of 2018 and 12 April.<ref name="auto13">Jack Grove, '[https://www.timeshighereducation.com/features/uss-strike-and-the-winter-of-academics-discontent The USS strike and the winter of academics’ discontent]', ''Times Higher Education'' (12 April 2018).</ref>
Staff organised "teach-outs" off campus at "every university with a substantial picket line";<ref name="auto11">Sanjana Varghese, '[https://www.newstatesman.com/politics/education/2018/03/why-students-are-coming-out-support-their-striking-lecturers Why students are coming out in support of their striking lecturers] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180312083841/https://www.newstatesman.com/politics/education/2018/03/why-students-are-coming-out-support-their-striking-lecturers |date=12 March 2018 }}', ''The New Statesman'' (8 March 2018).</ref> these featured education sessions which tended to be left-wing or critical of recent changes in UK higher education,<ref name=":500">John Marenbon, '[https://www.timeshighereducation.com/blog/uss-strike-academics-are-wrong-walk-out USS strike: academics are wrong to walk out] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180307151221/https://www.timeshighereducation.com/blog/uss-strike-academics-are-wrong-walk-out |date=7 March 2018 }}', ''Times Higher Education'' (2 March 2018).</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.varsity.co.uk/news/14886 |title=Academics to hold alternative teach-outs during strike action |last=Lally |first=Catherine |date=21 February 2018 |work=Varsity|access-date= |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180308042141/https://www.varsity.co.uk/news/14886 |archivedate=8 March 2018 |df=}}</ref><ref>'[https://www.thebangoraye.com/bangor-university-staff-to-teach-out-during-strike/ Bangor University staff to ‘Teach-Out’ during strike] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180308041633/https://www.thebangoraye.com/bangor-university-staff-to-teach-out-during-strike/ |date=8 March 2018 }}', ''The Bangor Aye'' (20 February 2018).</ref><ref>Jana Bacevic, '[https://www.timeshighereducation.com/blog/uss-strike-picket-line-debates-will-re-energise-scholarship USS strike: picket line debates will re-energise scholarship]', ''Times Higher Education'' (13 March 2018).</ref> apparently led by the University of Leeds, whose UCU branch had tested the model during a local dispute in autumn 2017.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.leedsucu.org.uk/organising-a-teach-out/ |title=Organising a teach-out |last= |first= |date=15 December 2017 |website=University of Leeds UCU|access-date= |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180308042724/http://www.leedsucu.org.uk/organising-a-teach-out/ |archivedate=8 March 2018 |df=}}</ref><ref>Lesley McCorrigan, 'Fourteen Days, Hold Tight: Reflections from Leeds on the USS Strike', ''Another Education is Possible'', 10 (Spring 2018), 12-13.</ref> Some pickets also featured staff singing rewrites of popular songs, among them Leeds University UCU's ''Strike Up Your Life'' (based on the [[Spice Girls]]' hit ''[[Spice Up Your Life]]'')<ref name="auto10"/> or dance routines, prominently including Cambridge University UCU's performance to [[Public Enemy (band)|Public Enemy's]] ''[[Fight the Power (Public Enemy song)|Fight the Power]]''.<ref>'[https://scroll.in/video/871677/watch-cambridge-university-teachers-show-off-funky-dance-moves-in-protest-against-pension-cuts Watch: Cambridge University teachers show off funky dance moves in protest against pension cuts]', ''Scroll.in'' (13 March 2018).</ref><ref>Ellie Mullett, '[https://www.varsity.co.uk/violet/15128 Striking Cambridge dons dance for their pensions in flash mob video] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180318054756/https://www.varsity.co.uk/violet/15128 |date=18 March 2018 }}', ''Violet by Varsity'' (11 March 2018).</ref> Meanwhile, Southampton University UCU's 'Dinosaur of Solidarity', a person in a dinosaur costume, became a minor social-media sensation.<ref>Arun Aggarwal, '[https://southampton.web.ucu.org.uk/2018/03/12/interview-with-a-dinosaur/ Interview with a Dinosaur]' (12 March 2018).</ref>
As the strikes commenced, academics at Oxford and Cambridge began using those universities' democratic structures to change the universities' position on pension reform.<ref name="auto7" /><ref name=":3">Richard Adams, '[https://www.theguardian.com/education/2018/mar/02/uk-universities-threaten-punish-striking-staff-cancelled-lectures Universities threaten to punish striking staff over cancelled lectures] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180316183535/https://www.theguardian.com/education/2018/mar/02/uk-universities-threaten-punish-striking-staff-cancelled-lectures |date=16 March 2018 }}', ''The Guardian'' (2 March 2018).</ref> Oxford staff's attempts to use the university's supreme governing body, [[Congregation (university)|Congregation]], to effect a change of policy failed due to procedural problems on 5 March, but the next day Oxford's vice-chancellor [[Louise Richardson]] declared that the University would nonetheless heed the wishes of staff to "reverse its response to the UUK survey".<ref>Richard Adams, '[https://www.theguardian.com/education/2018/mar/07/oxford-university-backs-down-in-pensions-dispute Oxford University backs down in pensions dispute] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180316183526/https://www.theguardian.com/education/2018/mar/07/oxford-university-backs-down-in-pensions-dispute |date=16 March 2018 }}', ''The Guardian'' (7 March 2018).</ref>
