As the strikes developed, university staff increasingly called into question the governance structures of UUK, individual universities, and USS, along with the marketisation of the UK higher education sector and its increasingly precarious workforce.<ref>Christopher Phelps, '[https://www.dissentmagazine.org/online_articles/uk-lecturers-strike-university-pensions-austerity-student-solidarity Britain: Universities on Strike] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180319151314/https://www.dissentmagazine.org/online_articles/uk-lecturers-strike-university-pensions-austerity-student-solidarity |date=19 March 2018 }}', ''Dissent'' (15 March 2018).</ref><ref name="auto4" /><ref>Richard Watermeyer, '[https://www.timeshighereducation.com/blog/uss-strike-academics-and-football-fans-are-fed-dehumanising-conditions USS strike: academics (and football fans) are fed up with ‘dehumanising’ conditions] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180321193041/https://www.timeshighereducation.com/blog/uss-strike-academics-and-football-fans-are-fed-dehumanising-conditions |date=21 March 2018 }}', ''Times Higher Education'' (20 March 2018).</ref><ref>Celine Tan, '[http://slsablog.co.uk/blog/blog-posts/uss-strikes-defending-the-collective-public-goods-mandate-of-the-uk-universities/ USS Strikes: Defending the Collective Public Goods Mandate of the UK Universities]', ''SLSA Blog'' (16 March 2018).</ref> By 13 April, over 12,000 people had signed a petition calling for UUK to be made subject to the [[Freedom of Information Act 2000]].<ref name="auto13" />
Staff also made extensive use of social media (see below).
===Universities===
Universities were represented in the dispute by UUK.
However, some vice-chancellors expressed support for UCU's position before the strike. [[Anthony Forster (academic)|Anthony Forster]], vice-chancellor at the [[University of Essex]], described a staff consultation process that led Essex to support retaining defined benefits via increased pension contributions.<ref>Anthony Forster, '[https://www.timeshighereducation.com/blog/universities-must-pay-more-protect-pensions Universities must pay more to protect pensions] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180310201015/https://www.timeshighereducation.com/blog/universities-must-pay-more-protect-pensions |date=10 March 2018 }}', ''Times Higher Education'' (19 February 2018).</ref> The [[University of Warwick]]'s [[Stuart Croft (academic)|Stuart Croft]] publicly stated that "I am sure that I am not alone in being mystified at this [proposed] change",<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://blogs.warwick.ac.uk/execteam/entry/which_way_forward/ |title=Which way forward for USS?, 28/11/17, VC blog |website=blogs.warwick.ac.uk|access-date=6 February 2018}}</ref> and argued, in line with the position of the Liberal Democrats, that the UK government should underwrite USS pensions.<ref>Stuart Croft, '[https://www.timeshighereducation.com/blog/uss-strike-it-time-nationalise-university-pensions USS strike: is it time to nationalise university pensions?] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180316041053/https://www.timeshighereducation.com/blog/uss-strike-it-time-nationalise-university-pensions |date=16 March 2018 }}', ''Times Higher Education'' (26 February 2018).</ref>
After the strike began, other vice chancellors voiced concern about UUK's position, and by the second day of strike action, 18 were being reported as calling for renewed negotiations, or as supporting UCU's position.<ref>Todd Gillespie and Catherine Lally, '[https://www.varsity.co.uk/news/14919 Stephen Toope joins calls for renewed talks to end strikes] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180225181649/https://www.varsity.co.uk/news/14919 |date=25 February 2018 }}', ''Varsity'' (23 February 2018).</ref> Some joined staff on picket lines, among them [[Anton Muscatelli]] (Glasgow), [[Keith Burnett]] (Sheffield) and [[Robert Allison (academic)|Robert Allison]] (Loughborough).<ref>Sophie Inge, '[https://www.timeshighereducation.com/news/pensions-strike-poisons-relations-uk-campuses Pensions strike ‘poisons relations’ on UK campuses] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180312204748/https://www.timeshighereducation.com/news/pensions-strike-poisons-relations-uk-campuses |date=12 March 2018 }}', ''Times Higher Education'' (8 March 2018).</ref> In a letter to ''The Times'' of 16 March, the vice-chancellor of Cambridge University, [[Stephen Toope]], expressed sympathy with the concerns of staff and students about not only pensions, but also marketisation of UK universities,<ref>Stephen Toope, '[https://www.thetimes.co.uk/edition/comment/british-retaliation-against-russia-s-actions-p5hmpj8jh The future of UK universities]', ''The Times'' (16 March 2018), accessed from {{cite web |url=https://www.cam.ac.uk/news/the-future-of-uk-universities-vice-chancellors-blog |title=Archived copy |accessdate=21 March 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180319151339/https://www.cam.ac.uk/news/the-future-of-uk-universities-vice-chancellors-blog |archivedate=19 March 2018 |df=}}.</ref><ref>Rosemary Bennett, '[https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/turning-universities-into-businesses-caused-strikes-hzrxsv2q6 Turning universities into businesses ‘caused strikes’, says Cambridge vice-chancellor Stephen Toope]', ''The Times'' (16 March 2018).</ref><ref>Louis Ashworth, '[https://www.varsity.co.uk/news/15179 Toope attacks ‘fundamental error’ of university marketisation] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180319151252/https://www.varsity.co.uk/news/15179 |date=19 March 2018 }}', ''Varsity'' (16 March 2018).</ref> and held a wide-ranging public meeting with around 550 staff and students in [[Great St Mary's Church]], scheduling a further such meeting for 26 April.<ref>Noella Chye & Jack Conway, '[https://www.varsity.co.uk/news/15184 Hundreds of students gather to quiz Toope on pensions, divestment, and Prevent] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180319151315/https://www.varsity.co.uk/news/15184 |date=19 March 2018 }}', ''Varsity'' (16 March 2018).</ref>
Conversely, many universities demanded that staff reschedule teaching that had not been delivered during the strike, noting their right to deduct pay for [[partial performance]] if staff did not. However, a smaller number appeared to be committed to implementing deductions. Examples which attracted media attention included: {| class="wikitable" |+ !University !Threatened deduction |- |[[University of St Andrews]] |100%<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.st-andrews.ac.uk/media/human-resources/new-policy-section-documents/strike/FAQ%202018%207%20Feb.pdf |title=Human Resources Strike Action & Action Short of a Strike FAQ |last= |first= |date= |website=|access-date= |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180301212642/https://www.st-andrews.ac.uk/media/human-resources/new-policy-section-documents/strike/FAQ%202018%207%20Feb.pdf |archivedate=1 March 2018 |df=}}</ref><ref name=":3" /> |- |[[University of Sheffield]] |25%<ref name=":2" /><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.sheffield.ac.uk/hr/thedeal/pensionupdates/uss-valuation-industrial-action/faqs |title=Frequently Asked Questions |last= |first= |date= |website=|access-date=1 March 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180301080446/https://www.sheffield.ac.uk/hr/thedeal/pensionupdates/uss-valuation-industrial-action/faqs |archivedate=1 March 2018 |df=}}</ref> |- |[[University of Kent]] |50% per breach of contract<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.kent.ac.uk/human-resources/pensions/uss-industrial-action2018/kents-pay-policy.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180302232141/https://www.kent.ac.uk/human-resources/pensions/uss-industrial-action2018/kents-pay-policy.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2 March 2018 |title=Kent's pay policy during this period of industrial action |last= |first= |date= |website=|access-date=}}</ref> |- |[[University of Leeds]] |25%<ref>Sophie Inge, '[https://www.pressreader.com/uk/the-times-higher-education/20180222/281711205130993 Tensions Mount on Campus as USS Pensions Strike Looms] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180304231542/https://www.pressreader.com/uk/the-times-higher-education/20180222/281711205130993 |date=4 March 2018 }}', ''Times Higher Education'' (22 February 2018).</ref><ref>Kristian Johnson, '[https://www.leeds-live.co.uk/news/leeds-news/staff-hit-out-university-leeds-14351183 Staff hit out at the University of Leeds for 'penalising striking members twice'] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180303225212/https://www.leeds-live.co.uk/news/leeds-news/staff-hit-out-university-leeds-14351183 |date=3 March 2018 }}', ''LeedsLive'' (28 February 2018).</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.leedsucu.org.uk/ucu-calls-on-university-senior-management-to-drop-asos-25-deduction-plan/ |title=UCU calls on university senior management to drop ASOS 25% deduction plan |last= |first= |date= |website=|access-date=2 March 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180303050807/http://www.leedsucu.org.uk/ucu-calls-on-university-senior-management-to-drop-asos-25-deduction-plan/ |archivedate=3 March 2018 |df=}}</ref><ref>'[https://www.pressreader.com/uk/yorkshire-post/20180302/282364040175672/textview Universities urged not to withhold staff pay]', ''Yorkshire Post'' (2 March 2018).</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://thetab.com/uk/leeds/2018/03/07/we-spoke-to-leeds-alumni-who-are-withdrawing-their-donations-following-the-strikes-42035 |title=We spoke to Leeds alumni who are withdrawing their donations following the strikes |last=Maclure |first=Abbey |date=7 March 2018 |work=The Tab|access-date=7 March 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180308231631/https://thetab.com/uk/leeds/2018/03/07/we-spoke-to-leeds-alumni-who-are-withdrawing-their-donations-following-the-strikes-42035 |archivedate=8 March 2018 |df=}}</ref> |- |[[Keele University]] |20%<ref name=":3" /><ref>Kathie McInnes, '[https://www.stokesentinel.co.uk/news/local-news/union-boss-claims-university-punishing-1293687 Union boss claims university is 'punishing' striking academics by docking their pay twice over] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180306202540/https://www.stokesentinel.co.uk/news/local-news/union-boss-claims-university-punishing-1293687 |date=6 March 2018 }}', ''The Stoke Sentinel'' (3 March 2018).</ref> |} In Sheffield's case, pay deduction of 25% for partial performance, rising to 100% after five days, was initially threatened,<ref>Lee Peace, '[https://www.thestar.co.uk/news/striking-university-of-sheffield-lecturers-in-fresh-row-over-pay-deductions-1-9043737 Striking University of Sheffield lecturers in fresh row over 'pay deductions] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180304081438/https://www.thestar.co.uk/news/striking-university-of-sheffield-lecturers-in-fresh-row-over-pay-deductions-1-9043737 |date=4 March 2018 }}', ''The Star'' (2 March 2018).</ref> provoking alumni to threaten to withdraw donations. The University then explained that it would not implement deductions for partial performance.<ref name=":200">Dominic Penna, '[https://thetab.com/uk/sheffield/2018/03/01/breaking-former-students-are-withdrawing-donations-to-the-university-of-sheffield-over-draconian-strike-policy-30297 BREAKING: Former students are withdrawing donations to the University of Sheffield over ‘draconian’ strike policy] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180304081547/https://thetab.com/uk/sheffield/2018/03/01/breaking-former-students-are-withdrawing-donations-to-the-university-of-sheffield-over-draconian-strike-policy-30297 |date=4 March 2018 }}', ''The Tab'' (1 March 2018).</ref><ref name=":3" /> Similar developments occurred at St Andrews, with the Principal, [[Sally Mapstone]], writing that "having considered all matters in the round, I believe that our current policy to deduct pay at 100% for failure to reschedule classes cancelled due to strike action is inconsistent with this University's values and the store we place on our shared sense of community".<ref name=":100">{{cite web|url=http://www.thesaint-online.com/2018/03/lecturers-to-receive-pay-for-failing-to-reschedule-class-due-to-strikes/|title=Lecturers to receive pay for failing to reschedule class due to strikes|last=Smith|first=Annie|date=5 March 2018|work=The Saint|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180305154226/http://www.thesaint-online.com/2018/03/lecturers-to-receive-pay-for-failing-to-reschedule-class-due-to-strikes/|archive-date=5 March 2018|dead-url=|access-date=5 March 2018}}</ref> At Leeds, a number of external examiners resigned in protest at the university's plans, ongoing as of 10 March, to deduct pay for partial performance,<ref>Nathan Hyde, '[https://www.leeds-live.co.uk/news/leeds-news/examiners-resign-protest-after-university-14387728 Examiners resign in protest after University of Leeds threatens to dock striking lecturers' pay]', ''LeedsLive'' (10 March 2018); archived at: https://web.archive.org/web/20180318213931/https://www.leeds-live.co.uk/news/leeds-news/examiners-resign-protest-after-university-14387728.</ref><ref name="auto12" /> while [[Alice Goodman]], widow of the university's noted professor [[Geoffrey Hill]], addressed an open letter to the university's vice chancellor asking the University to reconsider its stance.<ref>Sarah Colvin, '[https://www.timeshighereducation.com/opinion/uk-academics-have-snapped-and-not-just-over-pensions UK academics have snapped – and not just over pensions]', ''Times Higher Education'' (22 March 2018).</ref><ref>Alice Goodman, '[https://www.lrb.co.uk/blog/2018/03/10/alice-goodman/an-open-letter-to-the-vice-chancellor-of-leeds-university/ An Open Letter to the Vice Chancellor of Leeds University]', ''LRB Blog'' (10 March 2018).</ref>
Video recording of lectures had become widespread in UK universities by 2016,<ref>John Elmes, '[https://www.timeshighereducation.com/news/universities-uncertain-about-lecture-capture-copyright Universities ‘uncertain’ about lecture-capture copyright'] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180321130440/https://www.timeshighereducation.com/news/universities-uncertain-about-lecture-capture-copyright |date=21 March 2018 }}, ''Times Higher Education'' (8 December 2016).</ref> and some universities sought to use lectures recorded in previous years to substitute for teaching missed during the strikes. This prompted renewed debates about what rights universities should claim in the intellectual output of their staff.<ref>Jack Grove, '[https://www.timeshighereducation.com/news/academics-must-sign-away-authorship-rights-recorded-lectures Academics ‘must sign away authorship rights’ to recorded lectures]', ''Times Higher Education'' (20 March 2018).</ref>
===Students=== [[File:Leeds University students supporting the 2018 USS Pension Strikes.jpg|thumb|Leeds University students supporting the 2018 USS Pension Strikes on International Women's Day]]
====Polls==== A [[Yougov]] poll of 738 undergraduate students conducted for UCU between 13 and 20 February 2018 found that nationally, 61% of students said they supported the strikes, with 19% opposed and the remainder unsure. At striking institutions, support was 66%, with 18% opposed.<ref name=":0">Sally Weale and Alexandra Topping, '[https://www.theguardian.com/education/2018/feb/22/lecturers-begin-14-day-strike-over-pensions University lecturers begin strike action over pensions] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180227014405/https://www.theguardian.com/education/2018/feb/22/lecturers-begin-14-day-strike-over-pensions |date=27 February 2018 }}', ''The Guardian'' (22 February 2018); 'UCU Pension Strike', {{cite web |url=http://www.ucu.org.uk/media/9234/YouGov-USS-strike-action-poll/spreadsheet/UK12225972_Pension_strike_UCU.xlsx |title=Archived copy |accessdate=16 March 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180228044350/http://www.ucu.org.uk/media/9234/YouGov-USS-strike-action-poll/spreadsheet/UK12225972_Pension_strike_UCU.xlsx |archivedate=28 February 2018 |df=}}.</ref> In February 2018, a poll of 1,500 students for ''[[Times Higher Education]]'' magazine found over half (51.8%) would support their lecturer in a walk-out and just under a third (29.3%) would not.<ref name=":6">{{cite web|url=https://www.timeshighereducation.com/news/students-split-over-support-uss-pensions-strike-poll-reveals|title=Students split over support for USS pensions strike, poll reveals|date=15 February 2018|work=Times Higher Education (THE)|language=en|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180225075404/https://www.timeshighereducation.com/news/students-split-over-support-uss-pensions-strike-poll-reveals|archivedate=25 February 2018|deadurl=no|access-date=12 March 2018|df=}}</ref> Support for the national strike was evenly balanced, with 38.4% in favour and 38.4% against.<ref name=":6" />
By 8 March, extensive student support for the strikes was still being reported, observing that students were joining with staff in solidarity against the marketisation of UK higher education.<ref name="auto11"/>
====Compensation====
Students, who in [[England]] had since 2012 paid fees covering most of the cost of their education, responded by demanding compensation from their universities, explicitly in support of the striking staff: by 20 February, 70,000 had signed letters and petitions of this kind,<ref>Sally Weale, '[https://www.theguardian.com/education/2018/feb/20/70000-students-call-for-compensation-over-ucu-lecturer-strike 70,000 students call for compensation over UCU lecturer strike] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180227003554/https://www.theguardian.com/education/2018/feb/20/70000-students-call-for-compensation-over-ucu-lecturer-strike |date=27 February 2018 }}', ''The Guardian'' (20 February 2018).</ref> rising to around 126,000 by 5 March.<ref name=":400">{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/education-43295334 |title=University strike talks suspended without agreement |last=Burns |first=Judith |date=5 March 2018 |work=BBC news|access-date=5 March 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180305225924/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/education-43295334|archive-date=5 March 2018|dead-url=}}</ref>
On 4 March 2018, it was reported that [[King's College London]] had become the first university to offer to use money not spent on striking staff's salaries to compensate students.<ref>Sian Griffiths, '[https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/kings-college-london-students-offered-refund-over-lecturers-strike-bmf0czbc6 King’s College London offers student refunds over lecturers’ strike]', ''The Sunday Times'' (4 March 2018).</ref><ref>Sylvie Dumont, '[https://thetab.com/uk/kings/2018/03/04/breaking-kcl-is-offering-refunds-to-students-for-the-ucu-strikes-20744 King’s College London is offering refunds to students for the lecturer strikes] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180305062922/https://thetab.com/uk/kings/2018/03/04/breaking-kcl-is-offering-refunds-to-students-for-the-ucu-strikes-20744 |date=5 March 2018 }}', ''The Tab'' (4 March 2018).</ref> Robert Liow, a third year law student at the university, told the [[BBC]] that if universities did not refund students part of their fees, they would be profiting from the dispute, as they would gain the money not paid to striking university staff:<blockquote>I don't want a consumerist education service. I believe education is a public good and not a service to be sold. But if we are going to be treated as consumers we are going to ask for our money back.<ref name=":5" /></blockquote>On 23 March, it was reported that the international disputes lawyers Asserson had begun co-ordinating a no-win no-fee suit for compensation for students affected by the strikes, inviting students to sign up to participate via https://www.universitycompensation.co.uk/.<ref>Jamie Barlow, '[https://www.nottinghampost.com/news/nottingham-news/international-law-firm-launches-claim-1378812 International law firm launches claim for University of Nottingham students to receive compensation amid strike action]', ''Nottingham Post'' (23 March 2018).</ref> On 24 April, it was announced that over 1,000 students had signed up: enough to apply for a [[Group Litigation Order|group litigation order]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.timeshighereducation.com/news/students-bid-uk-strike-compensation-passes-legal-milestone|title=Students’ bid for UK strike compensation ‘passes legal milestone’|date=2018-04-24|work=Times Higher Education (THE)|access-date=2018-04-24|language=en}}</ref> By 17 June, over 5,000 had joined. Asserson estimated that one million students had been affected by the strike, with 575,000 teaching hours lost. They suggested that universites might be liable for £20m compensation.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.timeshighereducation.com/news/thousands-uk-students-join-pensions-strike-compensation-claim|title=Thousands of UK students join pensions strike compensation claim|last=|first=|date=|work=|access-date=}}</ref>
====Occupations and other activism==== On the first day of the strikes the UUK head office in London was occupied by students.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thenationalstudent.com/Student/2018-02-22/universities_uk_offices_occupied_by_students_as_part_of_ussstrike.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=16 March 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180316214510/http://www.thenationalstudent.com/Student/2018-02-22/universities_uk_offices_occupied_by_students_as_part_of_ussstrike.html |archivedate=16 March 2018 |df=}}</ref> Students undertook occupations of university buildings in support of the strike at various institutions, including [[University College London]] (26 February),<ref>{{cite web |url=https://thetab.com/uk/london/2018/02/27/ucl-strike-occupiers-stop-the-provost-from-getting-into-his-office-31457 |title=UCL strike occupiers stop the Provost from getting into his office |last=Bacon |first=Lucy |date=27 February 2018 |work=The Tab|access-date=5 March 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180306083355/https://thetab.com/uk/london/2018/02/27/ucl-strike-occupiers-stop-the-provost-from-getting-into-his-office-31457 |archivedate=6 March 2018 |df=}}</ref> the [[University of Liverpool]] (28 February)<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/news/liverpool-news/university-liverpool-students-occupy-vice-14343772 |title=University of Liverpool students 'occupy' Vice Chancellor's office |last=Traynor |first=Luke |date=27 February 2018 |work=The Liverpool Echo|access-date=5 March 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180304081541/https://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/news/liverpool-news/university-liverpool-students-occupy-vice-14343772|archive-date=4 March 2018|dead-url=}}</ref> and the [[University of Bristol]] (5 March),<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-bristol-43292861 |title=Bristol students stage staff pensions strike occupation |last= |first= |date= |work=|access-date=}}</ref> along with students at Leicester, Bath, Exeter, Southampton, Sussex, and Reading.<ref name="auto1"/> A fresh wave of occupations began on 12 March, following the publication of the first ACAS-brokered joint agreement between UCU and UUK, which UCU members rejected. Universities with occupations during that week included Reading,<ref>Luke Adams,'[http://www.readingchronicle.co.uk/news/16083906.Students_call_for_university_s_vice_chancellor_to_resign_during_hunger_strike/ Protesters refused to leave to support lecturers at the University of Reading] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180319084822/http://www.readingchronicle.co.uk/news/16083906.Students_call_for_university_s_vice_chancellor_to_resign_during_hunger_strike/ |date=19 March 2018 }}', ''The Reading Chronicle'' (13 March 2018).</ref> Cambridge (in the [[Old Schools]]),<ref>Oliver Guest and Todd Gillespie, '[https://www.varsity.co.uk/news/15145 Student activists occupy Old Schools in support of strikes] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180316023037/https://www.varsity.co.uk/news/15145 |date=16 March 2018 }}', ''Varsity'' (12 March 2018).</ref> Dundee,<ref>Nadia Vidinova, [https://www.thecourier.co.uk/fp/news/local/dundee/616612/dundee-university-students-occupy-tower-building-night-support-striking-lecturers/ Dundee University students occupy Tower building all night in support of striking lecturers] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180316084802/https://www.thecourier.co.uk/fp/news/local/dundee/616612/dundee-university-students-occupy-tower-building-night-support-striking-lecturers/ |date=16 March 2018 }}', ''The Courier'' (13 March 2018).</ref> York (in [[Heslington Hall]]),<ref>Chloe Laversuch, '[https://www.yorkpress.co.uk/educationnews/news/16083438.Students_occupy_Heslington_Hall_in_support_of_lecturers_in_pension_dispute/ York University students occupy Heslington Hall in support of lecturers in pension dispute]', ''The Press'' (13 March 2018).</ref> Sheffield (in the [[Arts Tower]]),<ref>Dominic Penna, "We will not tolerate any strikebreaking": Stirling students stage occupation in support of UCU strike] March 2018 }}', ''Commonspace'' (14 March 2018).</ref> Aberdeen,<ref>'[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-north-east-orkney-shetland-43400643 Police called to University of Aberdeen protest] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180314215445/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-north-east-orkney-shetland-43400643 |date=14 March 2018 }}', ''BBC News'' (14 March 2018).</ref> Surrey,<ref>Joe Burn, '[https://www.getsurrey.co.uk/news/surrey-news/university-surrey-strikes-students-occupy-14410433 University of Surrey strikes: Students occupy Senate House in support of ongoing UCU pensions dispute] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180316151725/https://www.getsurrey.co.uk/news/surrey-news/university-surrey-strikes-students-occupy-14410433 |date=16 March 2018 }}', ''Get Surrey'' (14 March 2018).</ref> Sussex,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://thetab.com/uk/sussex/2018/03/15/forty-students-occupy-new-east-slope-accommodation-construction-site-26510 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=16 March 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180316214649/https://thetab.com/uk/sussex/2018/03/15/forty-students-occupy-new-east-slope-accommodation-construction-site-26510 |archivedate=16 March 2018 |df=}}</ref> and Glasgow.<ref>'[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-glasgow-west-43413006 Students occupy Glasgow uni room in pension row] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180319095739/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-glasgow-west-43413006 |date=19 March 2018 }}', ''BBC News'' (15 March 2018).</ref>
The purpose of the occupations extended into other issues: on 19 March, University of London students occupied [[Senate House, London|Senate House]] in support of a strike called for 25–26 April by outsourced worked including cleaners, porters and receptionists.<ref>Sanjana Varghese, '[https://londonstudent.coop/news/2018/03/20/uol-premises-in-senate-house-occupied-by-students/ BREAKING: UoL premises in Senate House occupied by students]', ''London Student'' (20 March 2018).</ref> At one point during the occupation, students were locked into a room by staff members of the university.<ref>Ceren Sagir, '[https://morningstaronline.co.uk/article/university-of-london-seals-protesting-students-into-a-room University of London seals protesting students into a room]', ''Morning Star'' (22 March 2018).</ref>
In the wake of the February–March strikes, the students' union at [[SOAS]] called on its members to refuse to submit work with deadlines before 23 March, arguing that deadlines so soon after the end of the strikes would negatively affect students' work.<ref>Safa Daud, '[https://londonstudent.coop/news/2018/03/18/soas-su-calls-for-student-boycott-of-coursework-deadlines/ SOAS SU calls for student boycott of coursework deadlines]', ''London Student'' (18 March 2018).</ref>
===Politicians===
On 29 November 2017, [[Carol Monaghan]] (Scottish National Party) tabled an [[Early Day Motion]] in the [[House of Commons]] entitled "Defending Academic Pensions", noting "with concern the proposal by Universities UK to close the defined benefit portion of the Universities Superannuation Scheme (USS) to all future service". The motion was sponsored by [[Caroline Lucas]] (Green Party), [[Martyn Day (politician)|Martyn Day]] and [[Pete Wishart]] (SNP), and [[Jim Cunningham (British politician)|Jim Cunningham]], and [[Mary Glindon]] (Labour). As of 19 March, it had been signed by 133 MPs.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.parliament.uk/edm/2017-19/619/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=16 March 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180317102206/https://www.parliament.uk/edm/2017-19/619/ |archivedate=17 March 2018 |df=}}.</ref><ref>Djuna Thurley, '[https://dera.ioe.ac.uk/31113/1/CBP-8156_Redacted.pdf Universities Superannuation Scheme (USS)]', House of Commons Library, briefing paper CBP-8156 (20 February 2018), p. 14.</ref>
During the first week of industrial action, UCU's stance was explicitly supported by the Labour<ref>Emma Bartlett, '[https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/politics/jeremycorbynsends-solidarity-thanks-lecturers-university-12069042 Jeremy Corbyn sends 'solidarity and thanks' to lecturers and other university staff who begin a month of walkouts over pensions] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180304081459/https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/politics/jeremycorbynsends-solidarity-thanks-lecturers-university-12069042 |date=4 March 2018 }}', ''The Mirror'' (22 February 2018).</ref> and Green Parties.<ref>Liam Soutar, '[https://www.wigantoday.net/news/politics/backing-for-lecturers-strike-1-9032979 Backing for lecturers’ strike] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180223193630/https://www.wigantoday.net/news/politics/backing-for-lecturers-strike-1-9032979 |date=23 February 2018 }}', ''Wigan Today'' (23 February 2018).</ref> The Liberal Democrats argued that the government should underwrite the USS pension scheme, easing its assessment of risk.<ref>Lizzy Buchan, '[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/university-strike-lecturers-pensions-government-vince-cable-a8225801.html University strikes: Ministers urged to step in to guarantee lecturers' pensions after mass walkouts]', ''The Independent'' (24 February 2018).</ref> The Conservative universities minister [[Sam Gyimah]] encouraged the parties to negotiate, and encouraged universities to compensate students for missed education.<ref>Eleanor Busby, '[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/education/education-news/university-strikes-compensation-lecturers-students-sam-gyimah-direct-minister-latest-a8232746.html University strikes: Students set to receive 'direct compensation' over lectures missed due to action, minister says] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180311071501/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/education/education-news/university-strikes-compensation-lecturers-students-sam-gyimah-direct-minister-latest-a8232746.html |date=11 March 2018 }}', ''The Independent'' (28 February 2018).</ref>
The Chinese embassy in the UK also made representations to the Department for Education, expressing concern for the situation of Chinese students in the UK.<ref name=":3" /><ref>'[http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2018-03/01/c_137006815.htm Chinese embassy concerned as lasting UK university strike affects students] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180303105726/http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2018-03/01/c_137006815.htm|date=3 March 2018}}', ''China-Europe'' (1 March 2018).</ref>
===Scholarly societies===
Some scholarly societies issued statements supporting the strike, among them [[History UK]], which said it 'believes universities should try to maintain the conditions of employment under which academics were originally employed. That includes pensions.'<ref>'[https://www.history-uk.ac.uk/2018/03/05/huk-statement-on-current-industrial-action/ HUK statement on current industrial action]' (5 March 2018)</ref><ref>George Gosling, '[https://www.socialhistory.org.uk/2018/03/10/shs-statement-on-the-uss-pensions-dispute/ SHS Statement on the USS Pensions Dispute]' (10 March 2018).</ref> Others did not take a position but did publicly discuss the issues, among them the [[British Psychological Society]].<ref>Julianna Challenor, Trudi Edginton, Deborah Rafalin, Carla Willig, '[https://thepsychologist.bps.org.uk/volume-31/april-2018/call-support-pensions-dispute Call to support in pensions dispute]', ''The Psychologist'', 31 (April 2018), 1-2.</ref>
===Media===
==== Traditional media ==== The action attracted national television coverage,<ref>E.g. Jane Deith, '[https://www.channel4.com/news/university-staff-strike-over-pensions University staff strike over pensions] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180304081457/https://www.channel4.com/news/university-staff-strike-over-pensions|date=4 March 2018}}', ''Channel 4 News'' (22 February 2018).</ref> and supportive editorials from newspapers including the ''Observer''<ref>'[https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/feb/25/observer-view-on-the-shambolic-way-universities-are-run?CMP=share_btn_fb The Observer view on the shambolic way universities are run] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180301044621/https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/feb/25/observer-view-on-the-shambolic-way-universities-are-run?CMP=share_btn_fb |date=1 March 2018 }}', ''The Observer'' (25 February 2018).</ref> and the ''Financial Times'', which opined that "the universities must increase their pensions offer, and lecturers should give a fair hearing to any new proposals. Failing that, students should be compensated by the colleges".<ref name="auto2" /> Support for UUK, meanwhile, was offered in ''The Times'', with [[Daniel Finkelstein]], for example, arguing that "the pension fund is a pot of money shared between current and past staff. All that the trustees and the regulator are trying to do is to make sure it is fairly shared out. They are ensuring the money hasn't all been given away while there are people with future claims against it".<ref>Daniel Finkelstein, '[https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/lecturers-can-t-expect-us-to-pay-their-pensions-nsq30t2fw Lecturers can’t expect us to pay their pensions]', ''The Times'' (27 February 2018).</ref>
A number of commentators expressed exasperation at a tendency in the media, and on social media, to refer to the strike as a "lecturers' strike", when it involved a wide range of staff, academic and non-academic.<ref>Fiona Whelan, '[https://www.timeshighereducation.com/blog/uss-strike-why-arent-more-administrative-staff-picket-lines USS strike: why aren’t more administrative staff on picket lines?]', ''Times Higher Education'' (28 February 2018).</ref>
====Social media==== UCU members made extensive use of social media during the dispute. They were used to disseminate activists' research on the changes to pensions.<ref>Sherrill Stroschein, '[https://www.timeshighereducation.com/blog/uss-strike-social-media-has-collapsed-case-pension-cuts USS strike: social media has collapsed the case for pension cuts]', ''Times Higher Education'' (12 March 2018).</ref> Social media were also used to satirise universities' senior management: for example, the hashtag #FindMyProvost was used to mock vice-chancellors who did not engage with staff.<ref name="auto9"/> They were also a powerful organising tool. A prominent example was the Twitter hashtag '''''#NoCapitulation''''', which emerged as the unifying message university staff rallied behind twenty hours after the Acas agreement of 12 March.<ref name=":11" /> Dr Ed Rooksby, a tutor at [[Ruskin College]] Oxford said "The leadership saw this wave of hostility coming towards them and backed down," he says. "I'm sure there wouldn't have been as much momentum without Twitter, and without someone coming up with that hashtag."<ref name=":11" /> Dr. Jo Grady, a senior lecturer in employment relations at [[University of Sheffield|Sheffield University]], stated her belief that Twitter had helped people connect "outside of traditional union frameworks" and that this was ironic as their employers were the ones who encouraged staff to use social media as a tool for self-promotion.<ref name=":11" />
