{{Use mdy dates|date=January 2014}} {{Infobox writer | image = | name = Brendon Burchard | pseudonym = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1977|2|18}} | birth_place = [[Montana]] | death_date = | death_place = | occupation = Writer, High Performance Coach, Motivational Speaker | religion = | alma_mater = | genre = [[Nonfiction]] | movement = | notableworks = The Motivation Manifesto, High Performance Habits, The Millionaire Messenger }}
'''Brendon Burchard''' is a #1 ''New York Times'' best-selling author<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/04/03/books/bestseller/bestpaperbusiness.html|title=Paperback Business Best Sellers|date=2011-04-01|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-01-15|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> and "the world's leading high performance coach."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/kathycaprino/2016/10/11/the-worlds-leading-high-performance-coach-shares-3-steps-for-breaking-bad-habits/#739723b23ad4|title=The World's Leading High Performance Coach Shares 3 Steps For Breaking Bad Habits|last=Caprino|first=Kathy|work=Forbes|access-date=2018-01-15|language=en}}</ref> His latest book, ''High Performance Habits'', was a ''Wall Street Journal'' best-seller<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/best-selling-books-week-ended-oct-8-1507913917|title=Best-Selling Books Week Ended Oct. 8|date=2017-10-13|work=Wall Street Journal|access-date=2018-01-15|language=en-US|issn=0099-9660}}</ref> and named by Amazon as one of its top three best business and leadership books of 2017.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/b/ref=s9_acss_bw_cg_BOTY17_3a1_w?node=17296226011&pf_rd_m=ATVPDKIKX0DER&pf_rd_s=merchandised-search-4&pf_rd_r=PY49MC10Z222PTGNM79Q&pf_rd_t=101&pf_rd_p=db02bd39-6648-4745-a6ec-1f584ab4d4ae&pf_rd_i=17296226011|title=Business & Leadership @ Amazon.com|website=www.amazon.com|access-date=2018-01-15}}</ref> Burchard was on the cover of SUCCESS Magazine in October 2017 where the article named him the world's highest-paid motivation and marketing trainer.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.success.com/article/brendon-burchards-high-performance-habits|title=Brendon Burchard’s High Performance Habits|date=2017-09-01|work=SUCCESS|access-date=2018-01-15|language=en}}</ref> He has several online personal development courses with the Oprah Winfrey Network,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ownlifeclasses.com/|title=OWN Lifeclasses|website=www.ownlifeclasses.com|language=en|access-date=2018-01-15}}</ref> and according to Forbes he has trained over 1.5 million students in his online courses.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/kathycaprino/2016/10/11/the-worlds-leading-high-performance-coach-shares-3-steps-for-breaking-bad-habits/#16f20d403ad4|title=The World's Leading High Performance Coach Shares 3 Steps For Breaking Bad Habits|last=Caprino|first=Kathy|work=Forbes|access-date=2018-01-15|language=en}}</ref> ''O, The Oprah Magazine'', named him "one of the most influential leaders in the field of personal growth."<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.oprah.com/inspiration/oprah-talks-to-the-man-who-created-the-motivation-manifesto|title=What Oprah Learned About the Art of Motivation|work=Oprah.com|access-date=2018-01-15|language=en-us}}</ref> His podcast is called The Brendon Show.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/the-brendon-show/id821746377?mt=2|title=THE BRENDON SHOW by Brendon Burchard on Apple Podcasts|website=Apple Podcasts|language=en|access-date=2018-01-15}}</ref>
==Career== Burchard cites surviving a car accident at age 19 as the inspiration for his core teaching questions: “''Did I live? Did I love? Did I matter?''”<ref name=cbn>{{cite web|title=Author Shares Keys to Living a Fully Charged Life|url=http://www.cbn.com/cbnnews/us/2012/May/Author-Shares-Keys-to-Living-a-Fully-Charged-Life/|publisher=Christian Broadcasting Network}}</ref> His video about his story became a viral hit, with over 27 million views.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://business.facebook.com/brendonburchardfan/posts/1764113320288954|title=Brendon Burchard - Live. Love. Matter.|website=business.facebook.com|language=en|access-date=2018-01-15}}</ref>
Burchard is the founder of the Experts Academy and High Performance Academy.<ref name="inc">{{cite web|url=http://www.inc.com/marla-tabaka/brendon-burchard-the-millionaire-messenger.html|title=Brendon Burchard, the Millionaire Messenger|last=Tabaka|first=Marla|date=July 25, 2011|publisher=Inc.}}</ref> Both training programs provide students Burchard's lessons in business, entrepreneurship, psychology, productivity, and persuasion.<ref name=huff>{{cite web|last=Grisanti|first=Jen|title=Accepting Your Role as the Messenger|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/jen-grisanti/accepting-your-role-as-th_b_895246.html|publisher=Huffington Post|date=July 12, 2011}}</ref>
In 2011, Burchard's second book, ''The Millionaire Messenger'' was published and reached #1 on the ''[[New York Times]]'' best seller list that year.<ref name=nytimes>{{cite web|title=Bestsellers: Paperback Advice|url=https://www.nytimes.com/best-sellers-books/2011-04-03/paperback-advice/list.html|publisher=New York Times}}</ref> ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'', ''[[USA Today]]'', and [[Amazon.com]] bestseller lists.<ref name=inc/><ref>{{cite web|title=The Millionaire Messenger|url=http://books.usatoday.com/book/brendon-burchard-the-millionaire-messenger/l30673|publisher=USA Today}}</ref>
In 2012 his book ''The Charge: Activating the 10 Human Drives That Make You Feel Alive'' reached #1 on the ''Wall Street Journal'' bestseller list.<ref name=wsj>{{cite web|title=Best-Selling Books, Week Ended May 20|url=https://www.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424052702304019404577420352685994894|publisher=Wall Street Journal}}</ref>
In 2012, [[Mashable]] named Burchard at the top of their "Must-Follow Twitter Accounts for Daily Inspiration".<ref name=mashable>{{cite web|author= Pittman, Amanda|title=11 Must-Follow Twitter Accounts for Daily Inspiration|url=http://mashable.com/2012/08/10/twitter-inspiration/|publisher=Mashable}}</ref>
In 2014, his book The Motivation Manifesto spent 32 weeks on the ''New York Times'' best-seller list.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/books/best-sellers/2014/11/16/advice-how-to-and-miscellaneous/|title=Advice, How-To & Miscellaneous Books - Best Sellers - November 16, 2014 - The New York Times|access-date=2018-01-15|language=en}}</ref>
In 2016, he was named a member of Oprah Winfrey Network's Super Soul 100.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.supersoul.tv/supersoul-100/soul-teachers/brendon-burchard|title=Brendon Burchard - SuperSoul 100|date=2016-08-03|work=SuperSoul.tv|access-date=2018-01-15|language=en-US}}</ref>
In 2017, his book High Performance Habits became a Wall Street Journal best-seller<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/best-selling-books-week-ended-oct-8-1507913917|title=Best-Selling Books Week Ended Oct. 8|date=2017-10-13|work=Wall Street Journal|access-date=2018-01-15|language=en-US|issn=0099-9660}}</ref> and was #2 on Amazon's "Best business and leadership books of 2017" list.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/b/ref=s9_acss_bw_cg_BOTY17_2c1_w?node=17296226011&pf_rd_m=ATVPDKIKX0DER&pf_rd_s=merchandised-search-6&pf_rd_r=JPZEVHHCB5219ZXDJ3VT&pf_rd_t=101&pf_rd_p=ee4c19b5-e6a2-4729-80fb-366abeedcf6d&pf_rd_i=17276804011|title=Business & Leadership @ Amazon.com|website=www.amazon.com|access-date=2018-01-15}}</ref>
==Bibliography== * ''Life's Golden Ticket: An Inspirational Novel'' (2008) {{ISBN|0061173916}} * ''The Millionaire Messenger'' (2011) {{ISBN|1451665997}} * ''The Charge: Activating the 10 Human Drives that Make You Feel Alive'' (2012) {{ISBN|1451667531}} * ''The Motivation Manifesto: 9 Declarations to Claim Your Personal Power'' (2014) * ''High Performance Habits: How Extraordinary People Become That Way'' (2017)
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== * [http://brendon.com/ Official website]
==Further reading== *{{cite news|last1=|first1=|url=http://www.supersoul.tv/supersoul-100/soul-teachers/brendon-burchard|title=Super Soul 100|work=SuperSoul.tv|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|date=}} *[https://www.success.com/article/brendon-burchards-high-performance-habits Cover story, Success Magazine]. *[http://www.oprah.com/inspiration/oprah-talks-to-the-man-who-created-the-motivation-manifesto O, The Oprah Magazine].
{{DEFAULTSORT:Burchard, Brendon}} [[Category:American motivational speakers]] [[Category:American motivational writers]] [[Category:American self-help writers]] [[Category:Life coaches]] [[Category:American Internet celebrities]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1977 births]]

revision.comment: more sources; remove notability tag. If you disagree, take it to AfD.
revision.text:
[[File:Bushra Hyder from Pakistan.jpg|thumb|Bushra Hyder in 2015.]] '''Bushra Hyder''' is a [[Pakistani people|Pakistani]] schoolteacher and peace activist.<ref name="ican"/><ref name="huffpost"/> Hyder has a Master's in English literature.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wef.org.in/bushra-hyder-pakistan/|title=Bushra Hyder - Pakistan - WEF|publisher=[[Women Economic Forum]]|accessdate=2 August 2018}}</ref>
Hyder founded and runs the Qadims Lumiere School and College in [[Peshawar]], Pakistan,<ref name="huffpost"/> which had 1000 students in 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.meridian.org/project/against-all-odds-in-pakistan-women-combatting-radicalization/|title=Against All Odds in Pakistan: Women Combatting Radicalization|publisher=Meridian|accessdate=2 August 2018}}</ref> The school places a heavy emphasis on its peace curriculum, introduced in 2009,<ref name="ican interview"/> which entails education on a variety of religions and cultures.<ref name="ican"/><ref name="huffpost"/> The aim of the curriculum is to prevent students from turning to jihad.<ref name="ican"/><ref name="ican interview"/> Hyder has lobbied to get other schools in the region and country to implement similar curricula.<ref name="ican"/><ref name="huffpost"/>
Hyder has co-founded the Women's Alliance for Security Leadership,<ref name="ican"/> and is a member of the PAIMAN Alumni Trust Pakistan, an anti-jihad organisation.<ref name="liputan6"/> She works with politicians and religious leaders to counter extremism.<ref name="inclusive"/>
==References== {{reflist|refs= <ref name="huffpost">{{cite web|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/shereen-hall/pakistan-female-leaders_b_1501214.html|title=12 Influential Pakistani Women Leaders You Should Know|work=[[HuffPost]]|last=Hall|first=Shereen|date=8 May 2012|accessdate=1 August 2018}}</ref> <ref name="ican">{{cite web|url=http://www.icanpeacework.org/2017/09/27/pakistani-peacebuilder-bushra-hyder-fighting-off-call-jihad-rohingya/|title=Pakistani peacebuilder, Bushra Hyder, fighting off call for jihad for Rohingya|publisher=International Civil Society Action Network|date=27 September 2017|accessdate=1 August 2018}}</ref> <ref name="ican interview">{{cite web|url=http://www.icanpeacework.org/2017/07/18/bushra-qadeem-hyder-pakistan/|title=Bushra Qadeem Hyder on Fighting Extremism with Education in Pakistan|publisher=International Civil Society Action Network|date=18 July 2017|accessdate=1 August 2018}}</ref> <ref name="liputan6">{{cite web|url=https://www.liputan6.com/global/read/2932734/kisah-bushra-hyder-perempuan-pembawa-misi-damai-di-pakistan|title=Kisah Bushra Hyder, Perempuan Pembawa Misi Damai di Pakistan|last=Prayitno|first=Panji|work=Liputan6|publisher=[[SCTV (Indonesia)|SCTV]]|language=Indonesian|date=26 April 2017|accessdate=1 August 2018}}</ref> <ref name="inclusive">{{cite web|url=https://www.inclusivesecurity.org/2015/01/28/17-women-changing-world/|title=17 Women Who Are Changing the World|publisher=Inclusive Security|last=Williams|first=Kristin|date=28 January 2015|accessdate=1 August 2018}}</ref> }}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Hyder, Bushra}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Founders of Pakistani schools and colleges]] [[Category:Pakistani schoolteachers]] [[Category:21st-century Pakistani people]] [[Category:Women educators]] [[Category:Education activists]]

page.title: Canadian English Language Proficiency Index Program

revision.comment: only updated the official website and the 3 official social media pages.
revision.text:
The '''Canadian English Language Proficiency Index Program''', or '''CELPIP''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|s|ɛ|l|p|ɪ|p}}), is an English [[language assessment]] tool which measures [[listening]], [[Reading (process)|reading]], [[writing]], and [[speaking]] skills. The test is administered by Paragon Testing Enterprises.,<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.paragontesting.ca/english-language-tests/|title = English Language Tests|date = |accessdate = 2015-09-23|website = www.paragontesting.ca|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> a subsidiary of the [[University of British Columbia]] (UBC). Paragon is the only Canadian company delivering [[Department of Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship|Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada]] (IRCC) designated English proficiency tests.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.celpiptest.ca/celpip-preparation-program/|title=CELPIP Preparation Program - CELPIPTest.ca|website=CELPIPTest.ca|language=en-US|access-date=2016-06-08}}</ref> The CELPIP test is offered in two versions, CELPIP-General, and CELPIP-General LS.
CELPIP-General is suitable for people who need proof of English-language skills when applying for permanent resident status in [[Canada]] under the [[Federal Skilled Worker Program]] (FSWP), [[Federal Skilled Trades Program]] (FSTP), [[Canadian experience class|Canadian Experience Class]] (CEC), [[Start-up Visa Program]], and various [[Provincial Nominee Programs]], or for [[employment]]. [[Department of Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship|Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada]] has two approved English language tests: CELPIP-General and [[International English Language Testing System|IELTS]] General Training Test: International English Language Testing System.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Where can I take a third-party language test for my immigration application?|url = http://www.cic.gc.ca/english/helpcentre/answer.asp?q=125&t=6|website = www.cic.gc.ca|accessdate = 2015-10-01}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Do I need a language test to immigrate to Canada?|url = http://www.cic.gc.ca/english/helpcentre/answer.asp?q=638&t=6|website = www.cic.gc.ca|accessdate = 2015-10-01}}</ref>
CELPIP-General LS is suitable for people who need proof of listening and speaking proficiency for [[Canadian citizenship]]. The CELPIP-General LS Test is accepted by IRCC as one of only two designated English language tests for Canadian citizenship.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Acceptable language proof to apply for citizenship wizard|url = http://www.cic.gc.ca/english/citizenship/language-step-6.asp|website = www.cic.gc.ca|accessdate = 2015-09-23}}</ref>
In June 2015, with the acquisition of the [[Canadian Academic English Language Assessment|Canadian Academic English Language]] (CAEL) Assessment, Paragon Testing Enterprises retired the CELPIP-Academic Test.
== CELPIP Test Types == [[File:CELPIP General Logo.jpg|CELPIP-General logo|border|right]]
=== CELPIP-General === The CELPIP-General Test assesses a general level of English-language proficiency. The CELPIP-General Test is accepted as proof of English language proficiency for those applying for [[Permanent residency in Canada|Canadian Permanent Residency]] and to the [[Association of Saskatchewan Realtors|Association of Saskatchewan REALTORS (ASR)]].
The forms of identification that are acceptable for CELPIP-General test registrations are: * a [[Passport]] Booklet * [[Refugee]] Protection Claimant Document* * [[Travel document|Travel Document]]* <nowiki>*</nowiki>Refugee Protection Claimant Documents and Travel Documents must be preapproved by Paragon Testing Enterprises. Refugee Protection Claimant Documents and Travel Documents that are not preapproved will not be accepted on test day.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.celpiptest.ca/test-day-information/|title=CELPIPTest.ca|website=CELPIPTest.ca|language=en-US|access-date=2016-05-12}}</ref>
=== CELPIP-General LS === [[File:CELPIP-General LS logo.jpg|CELPIP-General LS logo|border|right|204x204px]]The CELPIP-General LS Test assesses a general level of English-language proficiency. The CELPIP-General LS Test is accepted by Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada (IRCC) as a measure of listening and speaking proficiency for those applying for Canadian citizenship.
In June 2015, Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada (IRCC) implemented the remaining changes to the Citizenship Act. One important change is that applicants between the ages of 14 and 64 must now meet basic language requirements in listening and speaking in English or French. For minors who are between the ages of 14 and 17, registrations for the CELPIP-General LS Test are accepted.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.celpiptest.ca/2015/07/registration-for-minors/|title=Registration for Test Takers Under 18|date=2015-07-30|website=CELPIPTest.ca|language=en-US|access-date=2016-04-27}}</ref>
The forms of identification that are acceptable for CELPIP-General LS test registrations are: * Passport Booklet * Canadian Permanent Resident Card * Travel Document* <nowiki>*</nowiki>Refugee Protection Claimant Documents and Travel Documents must be preapproved by Paragon Testing Enterprises. Refugee Protection Claimant Documents and Travel Documents that are not preapproved may not be accepted on test day.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.celpiptest.ca/test-day-information/|title=CELPIPTest.ca|website=CELPIPTest.ca|language=en-US|access-date=2016-05-12}}</ref>
== Test Format ==
=== CELPIP-General === The test is completely computer-delivered, and consists of four sections: listening, reading, and writing and speaking.<ref>{{Cite web|title = CELPIP-General Test: Test Format and Scoring|url = https://www.celpiptest.ca/about-celpip-g/test-format-and-scoring/|website = www.celpiptest.ca|accessdate = 2015-10-02}}</ref> The Listening component is composed of eight parts, but only seven parts will be given during the test. The test taker will not be informed which part is to be omitted.The unscored items in the Reading and Listening section are used for test development. These unscored items can be found anywhere within the component and the test taker will not know which items will be unscored.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.celpiptest.ca/about-celpip-g/|title=CELPIPTest.ca|website=CELPIPTest.ca|language=en-US|access-date=2016-04-14}}</ref> The total length of all four sections is 180 minutes. {| class="wikitable" !Test Component !Time Allotted !Number of Questions !Component Sections |- | rowspan="8" |'''Listening''' | rowspan="8" |47 minutes |2 |Practice Test |- |8 |Part 1: Listening to Problem Solving |- |5 |Part 2: Listening to a Daily Life Conversation |- |6 |Part 3: Listening for Information |- |5 |Part 4: Listening to a News Item |- |8 |Part 5: Listening to a Discussion |- |6 |Part 6: Listening to Viewpoints |- |5–8 |Part 7: Unscored Items |- | rowspan="5" |'''Reading''' | rowspan="5" |60 minutes |11 |Part 1: Reading Correspondence |- |8 |Part 2: Reading to Apply a Diagram |- |9 |Part 3: Reading for Information |- |10 |Part 4: Reading for Viewpoints |- |8–11 |Part 7: Unscored Items |- | rowspan="2" |'''Writing''' | rowspan="2" |53 minutes |1 |Task 1: Writing an Email |- |1 |Task 2: Responding to Survey Questions |- | rowspan="9" |'''Speaking''' | rowspan="9" |20 minutes |1 |Practice Task |- |1 |Task 1: Giving Advice |- |1 |Task 2: Talking about a Personal Experience |- |1 |Task 3: Describing a Scene |- |1 |Task 4: Making Predictions |- |1 |Task 5: Comparing and Persuading |- |1 |Task 6: Dealing with a Difficult Situation |- |1 |Task 7: Expressing Opinions |- |1 |Task 8: Describing an Unusual Situation |}
=== CELPIP-General LS === The test is computer-based, and made up of two sections: listening and speaking.<ref>{{Cite web|title = CELPIP-General LS Test Format and Scoring|url = https://www.celpiptest.ca/celpip-general-ls/celpip-general-ls-test-format-and-scoring/|website = www.celpiptest.ca|accessdate = 2015-10-02}}</ref> The Listening component is composed of eight Listening parts, but only seven parts will be given during the test. The test taker will not be informed which part is to be omitted.
The total length of all four sections is 180 minutes. {| class="wikitable" !Test Component !Time Allotted !Number of Questions !Component Sections |- | rowspan="8" |'''Listening''' | rowspan="8" |47 minutes |2 |Part 1: Identifying Similar Meanings |- |8 |Part 2: Answering Questions |- |5 |Part 3: Listening to Problem Solving |- |6 |Part 4: Listening to a Daily Life Conversation |- |5 |Part 5: Listening for Information |- |8 |Part 6: Listening to a News Item |- |6 |Part 7: Listening to a Discussion |- |5-8 |Part 8: Listening to Viewpoints |- | rowspan="9" |'''Speaking''' | rowspan="9" |20 minutes |1 |Task 0: Practice Task |- |1 |Task 1: Giving Advice |- |1 |Task 2: Talking about a Personal Experience |- |1 |Task 3: Describing a Scene |- |1 |Task 4: Making Predictions |- |1 |Task 5: Comparing and Persuading |- |1 |Task 6: Dealing with a Difficult Situation |- |1 |Task 7: Expressing Opinions |- |1 |Task 8: Describing an Unusual Situation |}
== Scoring ==
Scores are released 8 business days online after the test taker's test date. Two [[Hard copy|hard copies]] of the Official CELPIP Score Report are then sent out with Canada Post Regular Mail.
Express Rating scores are released in the test taker's CELPIP account 3 business days after their test date. Express Rating is available, with an extra fee, for the CELPIP-General Test and the CELPIP-General LS Test. Hardcopies of the CELPIP Official Score Report are sent through Canada Post Express Post <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.celpiptest.ca/express-rating/|title=CELPIPTest.ca|website=CELPIPTest.ca|language=en-US|access-date=2016-04-25}}</ref>
The format and scoring of the CELPIP-General Test and the CELPIP-General LS Test are referenced to the [[Canadian Language Benchmarks]] (CLB). Below are the proficiency score levels and their CLB equivalents:<ref>{{Cite web|title = CELPIP Levels and Descriptors|url = https://www.celpiptest.ca/scores/proficiency-levels-and-their-descriptors/|website = www.celpiptest.ca|accessdate = 2015-09-23}}</ref> {| class="wikitable" |- ! CELPIP Level !! CELPIP Descriptor !! CLB Level |- | 12 || Advanced proficiency in workplace and community contexts || 12 |- | 11 || Advanced proficiency in workplace and community contexts || 11 |- | 10 || Highly effective proficiency in workplace and community contexts || 10 |- | 9 || Effective proficiency in workplace and community contexts || 9 |- | 8 || Good proficiency in workplace and community contexts || 8 |- | 7 || Adequate proficiency in workplace and community contexts || 7 |- | 6 || Developing proficiency in workplace and community contexts || 6 |- | 5 || Acquiring proficiency in workplace and community contexts || 5 |- | 4 || Adequate proficiency for daily life activities || 4 |- | 3 || Some proficiency in limited contexts || 3 |- | M || Minimal proficiency or insufficient information to assess || 0, 1, 2 |}
==Test Centre Locations== There are over 33 testing centres across Canada in addition to one test center in United Arab Emirates. However, CELPIP Test sittings are currently only available in Canada and United Arab Emirates, Dubai. For a full list of locations, please click [https://www.celpip.ca/test-locations-fees/ here].
==Exam Preparation Resources== One can prepare for the exam by taking free sample tests available through CELPIP online portal. Alternatively, Paragon provides an opportunity of taking a sample test in a real testing centre environment to all prospect clients. Among other resources, Paragon produces a wide selection of study materials for each module of the test. Finally, independent schools around the world offer exam prep programs to familiarize test takers with the exam format and help improve their level of English language.
Schools that offer CELPIP preparation program: * [https://www.ashtoncollege.ca/programs/celpip-preparation-program/ Ashton College] * [https://www.ccet.ca/celpip_toronto.php Canada College of Education] * [http://europals.ca/celpip-courses/ Europa Language School] * [https://hansacanada.com/english-programs/exam-preparation/celpip/ Hansa Language Centre] * [http://www.vttcenter.ca/celpip-preparation-program/ Vancouver TESOL Training Center]
=={{anchor|Other English proficiency tests}}See also== *[[Canadian Academic English Language Assessment|CAEL]] (Canadian Academic English Language Assessment) *[[Department of Citizenship and Immigration Canada|IRCC]] (Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada) *[[TOEIC]] (Test of English for International Communication) *[[TOEFL]] (Test of English as a Foreign Language) *[[IELTS]] (International English Language Testing System)
== Notes == {{Reflist}}
==References== * "Becoming an Immigration Consultant." Immigration Consultants of Canada Regulatory Council. Web. 25 May 2012. <https://www.iccrc-crcic.ca/students/becomingConsultant.cfm>. * "Skilled Workers and Professionals - Selection Factor: Language." Citizenship and Immigration Canada. 23 Oct. 2010. Web. 25 May 2012. <http://www.cic.gc.ca/english/immigrate/skilled/language-testing.asp>. * "English Proficiency Requirements." English Language Proficiency Requirements. The University of British Columbia. Web. 29 May 2012. <http://www.grad.ubc.ca/prospective-students/application-admission/english-proficiency-requirements>. * "Canadian English Language Proficiency Index Program (CELPIP)." Citizenship and Immigration Canada. Citizenship and Immigration Canada, 20 Jan. 2009. Web. 29 May 2012. <http://www.cic.gc.ca/english/resources/manuals/bulletins/2009/ob094.asp>. * "Test Format and Scoring." CELPIP Test - Academic. Paragon Testing Enterprises. Web. 29 May 2012. <http://www.celpiptest.ca/celpip-academic/about-celpip-a/test-format-and-content/>. * "Test Format and Scoring." CELPIP Test - General. Paragon Testing Enterprises. Web. 29 May 2012. <http://www.celpiptest.ca/celpip-general/about-celpip-g/test-format-and-scoring/>. * "About Paragon." Paragon Testing Enterprises. Web. 25 May 2012. <http://www.paragontesting.ca/about/>.
==External links== * {{Official website}} * {{Facebook}} * {{Twitter}} * {{YouTube|channel=UCsSYTLCLK0K2kq6hFSX476A}} * [[UBC]] (University of British Columbia) * [http://www.cic.gc.ca/ IRCC] (Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada)

revision.text:
'''Certified Measurement and Verification Professional''' ('''CMVP''') is an accreditation from the [[Efficiency Valuation Organization]] (EVO) and the [[Association of Energy Engineers]] (AEE) awarded to qualified professionals in the growing field of [[Measurement and Verification|Measurement & Verification]] (M&V) within the energy industry.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.evo-world.org |title=Efficiency Valuation Organization}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url= http://www.aeecenter.org/i4a/pages/index.cfm?pageid=3356 | title= Association of Energy Engineers CMVP Program}}</ref> Its aim is to acknowledge good practice and raise overall professional standards within the M&V field worldwide.
The right to use the CMVP post-nominal is granted to those who demonstrate proficiency in M&V and knowledge of the [[International performance measurement and verification protocol]] (IPMVP) by passing a 4-hour written exam and meeting the required academic and practical qualifications.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.evo-world.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=278&Itemid=400&lang=en | title= CMVP Eligibility Requirement}}</ref> The CMVP has then demonstrated the necessary capabilities to write an M&V Plan that adheres to the IPMVP.<ref>IPMVP Volume 1 Concepts and Options for Determining Energy and Water Savings</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Certified Measurement And Verification Professional}} [[Category:Qualifications]] [[Category:Energy conservation]]

revision.text:
{{redirect|Comenius Foundation|the American organization|Comenius Foundation (US)}} {{notability|Organizations|date=September 2010}} {{infobox Organization |name = Comenius Foundation for Child Development |image = Comenius-logo-eng.png |image_border = |size = 200px |caption = Foundation's English logo |abbreviation = |motto = Bo jakie początki, takie będzie wszystko
''For the beginnings determine all that follows'' |formation = September 2003 |type = NGO |status foundation |purpose = Child welfare |headquarters = Warsaw, Poland |location = |region_served = Poland |membership = |language = Polish |leader_title = President of the Board |leader_name = Teresa Ogrodzińska |main_organ = The Foundation's Board |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |budget = |website = [http://www.frd.org.pl/ www.frd.org.pl] |remarks = }} The '''Comenius Foundation for Child Development''', or '''Comenius Foundation''' for short (Polish: ''Fundacja Rozwoju Dzieci im. Komeńskiego'', or ''Fundacja Komeńskiego''), is a children's welfare [[non-governmental organisation]] based in [[Warsaw]], [[Poland]], established in September 2003. The Foundation's goal is to provide equal educational opportunities to children aged 3–5 years, particularly in rural areas of high unemployment, in response to a dramatic decline in [[preschool education]] services in Poland. Only 38% of children aged 3–5 attended [[kindergarten|pre-school]], which means that some 750,000 children in this age group is left out of pre-school care. In rural areas the attendance figure is below 10%. This is the lowest result in the whole [[European Union]]. The Foundation organises and conducts training for teachers, school and kindergarten headmasters, teachers and local educational authorities. The Foundation's "Where There Are No Pre-schools" programme aims at helping rural communities to develop new models for early-childhood education, based on local financial resources. A pilot scheme was set up in 28 rural [[gmina|communities]], where 75 Early Childhood Education Centres have been set up, with over 800 children. Educational activities are provided by teachers trained by the Comenius Foundation to use the project approach in the classroom. The local authorities cover the costs of the teachers' salaries and the premises, whereas the Foundation is responsible for financing the teacher training, monitoring the quality of teaching and setting up local libraries. An external evaluation of the programme, commissioned by the Foundation, will enable modification while the programme is being implemented. == References == *[http://www.frd.org.pl/ Official website] {{en icon}} {{pl icon}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20071213032247/http://www.frd.org.pl/old/annual_report_2004.pdf Annual Report 2004] == External links == *[http://sustainable-everyday.net/cases/?p=68 Comenius kindergartens]{{dead link|date=August 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20071024215633/http://www.bernardvanleer.org/partners/europe/poland_-_comenius_foundation_ Information about the "Where There Are No Preschools" programme] from [[Bernard van Leer Foundation]] [[Category:Early childhood education in Poland]] [[Category:Foundations based in Poland]] [[Category:Educational organisations in Poland]] [[Category:Organizations established in 2003]] [[Category:Educational foundations]] [[Category:Children's charities based in Poland]]

revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{external links|date=November 2012}} {{COI|date=December 2011}} {{advert|date=December 2011}} }}
<!-- Please leave this line alone! -->
'''Cultural Detective''' is designed to improve conditions and [[productivity]] in an [[international]] or [[multicultural]] environment. As an [[intercultural competence]] tool, it is designed to lessen [[stereotyping]] and improve [[dialogue]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://business.in.com/article/thunderbird/cultural-detective-avoid-crosscultural-trial-by-fire/17962/1|title=Avoid cross-cultural trial by fire|author=Kris Bibler|date=Oct 4, 2010|work=Business India}}</ref> Cultural Detective, while it is a registered trademark of a single business entity{{which|date=October 2016}}, it is also a project involving around 130 professionals from various places in the world.
The approach has been used on a proprietary basis by multinationals and NGOs in various locations around the world<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.expatica.com/hr/story/tools-to-develop-your-employees-intercultural-skills-25406.html|title=Tools to develop your employees' intercultural skills|date=November 17, 2005|author=Eleonore Breukel|website=Expatica.com|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080709053051/http://www.expatica.com/hr/story/tools-to-develop-your-employees-intercultural-skills-25406.html|archivedate=July 9, 2008}}</ref> since 1989, and has been publicly available since 2004.<ref>{{Cite web|date=May 2006|url=http://www.culturaldetective.com/humancapital.html|title=Product launch: Developing cross-cultural competence|author=Dr. Madhukar Shukla|publisher=Human Capital Magazine|location=India|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130212034306/http://www.culturaldetective.com/humancapital.html|archivedate=February 12, 2013|deadurl=yes}}</ref> It includes a series of culture- and topic-specific{{clarify|date=October 2016}} available via [[site license]] or online download. A [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UegICR2zMdk video] describes the core process.{{clarify|date=October 2016}}
Cultural Detective focuses on developing three capacities in its participants: # Know yourself as an individual and as a being made of influences of multiple cultures – Understand your (own) Subjective Culture.<ref>{{cite web|year=2009|url=http://www.culturaldetective.com/toolkitcurran.pdf|title=Cultural Detective: A tool for global diversity and inclusion practices|author=Kathleen Curran|work=Linkage Diversity Toolbox|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120425021436/http://www.culturaldetective.com/toolkitcurran.pdf|archivedate=April 25, 2012|deadurl=yes}}</ref> # Get to know others as individuals and as beings made of influences of multiple cultures – Acquire Cultural Literacy. # Fully include, utilize and appreciate everyone involved, with their similarities and differences as assets. Make sure systems and processes support interpersonal skills – Be a Cultural Bridge.
These capacities are developed through the Worksheet,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.expatriateconnect.com/news/building-cultural-bridges-how-to-attain-a-cultural-education|title=Building cultural bridges-How to attain a cultural education|author=Karen Huchendorf|work=ExpatriateCONNECT}}</ref> used to analyze the series' 1000+ critical incidents involving people from various cultures, industries and professional functions. The Worksheet is used for real-time [[conflict resolution]] and [[team-building]], as well as an individual's journal to analyze one's own life experiences. There is also discussion of values, both from various cultures and from examination of one's own set of values.
== Theoretical underpinnings == The Cultural Detective method is theoretically grounded yet practical, allowing for success because it focuses on the differences that make a difference in real situations. Theoretical concepts inherent in the method include: # [[Culture]] is a Lens that colors nearly everything we see, say and do, and the decisions we make. It largely dictates how we make meaning.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lcc.gatech.edu/~herrington/classes/4406f2000/barnlund.html|title=Communication in a Global Village|author=Dean Barnlund|work=Georgia Tech}}</ref> # Culture is an ever-changing dynamic not a static entity.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://cap.sagepub.com/content/7/3/283.short|title=Culture As Patterns: An Alternative Approach to the Problem of Reification|authors=G Adams & HR Markus|journal=Culture and Psychology|volume=7|number=3|pages=283–296|doi=10.1177/1354067X0173002}}</ref> # Intercultural competence is context-specific.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=0FYtvfvpphIC|title=Handbook of International and Intercultural Communication|year=2002|publisher=SAGE|authors=WB Gudykunst & B Mody|isbn=9780761920908}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=6pGHdHjKx14C|year=2008|title=The Global Intercultural Communication Reader|authors=Molefi Kete Asante, Yoshitaka Miike, & Jing Yin|page=219|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9780415958127}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mhUoAQAAIAAJ|year=2009|title=Intercultural Communication in Contexts|publisher=McGraw-Hill Education|authors=JN Martin & TK Nakayama|edition=5|isbn=9780073385129}}</ref> # People are complex amalgams of multiple cultural influences (age, gender, sexual orientation, spiritual tradition, education and training, nationality, ethnicity, organizational culture, etc.).<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://gbr.pepperdine.edu/2010/08/managing-in-an-era-of-multiple-cultures/|title=Managing in an Era of Multiple Cultures|authors=ME Phillips & SA Sackmann|journal=Graziado Business Review|publisher=Pepperdine University|year=2002|volume=5|issue=4}}</ref> # Nationality is not necessarily (or usually) the most powerful culture at play in an interaction.<ref>{{cite book|year=2005|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rEo1yTeEKz4C&pg=PA24&lpg=PA24|title=Communication Highwire: Leveraging the power of diverse communication styles|authors= DH Saphiere, BK Mikk & BI DeVries|publisher=Intercultural Press|page=24|isbn=9781931930154}}</ref> # The value of observation and objective description that attempts to filter out cultural bias and expectations<ref>{{cite book|year=2003|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lw_Yxq-HSsMC|title=Crossing Cultures: Insights from master teachers|authors=NA Boyacigiller, RA Goodman, ME Phillips, & JE Anderson|publisher=Psychology Press|page= 163|isbn=9780415308199}}</ref> # The link between [[values]] and [[human behavior]]<ref>{{cite book|year=2000|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Wych4q-CNlcC|title=Managing Organizational Behavior|authors=HL Tosi, NP Mero & JR Rizzo|page=63|publisher=Wiley|edition=4|isbn=9780631212577}}</ref> # The importance of recognizing [[positive intent]] # The distinction between intent and [[perception]]<ref>{{cite book|year=1994|publisher=SUNY Press|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=ca9pv_v2oEwC|title=The Challenge of Facework: Cross-cultural and interpersonal issues|author=Stella Ting-Toomey|page=243|isbn=9780791416341}}</ref> # The frequency and reasons for negative perception # Bridges between cultures must be two-way or multidirectional for long-term effectiveness and mutual benefit. # Organizations and communities must reinforce interpersonal competence with [[systems]], processes and [[structures]] that reward and develop those competencies.<ref>{{cite book|year=2009|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4KdhRIgmgvMC|title=The SAGE Handbook of Intercultural Competence|author=DK Deardorff|publisher=SAGE|page=224|isbn=9781412960458}}</ref> The [[metaphor]] of a [[detective]] reinforces many of the key approaches and theories of the method and helps those not skilled in this area to quickly grasp the concepts and use the tool.
== Connection with other models and approaches == Cultural Detective extends the earlier intercultural work of people such as [[Edward T Hall|Edward T. Hall]], Dean Barnlund, L. Robert Kohls,<ref>{{cite web|title=Robert Kohls; Official, Author Led Training in Overseas Life|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/09/01/AR2006090101637.html|work=Washington Post|accessdate=2 July 2015}}</ref> [[Clyde Kluckhohn|Clyde and Florence Kluckhohn]], and John C. Condon. It dovetails well<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.leidykla.vu.lt/fileadmin/Informacijos_mokslai/45/85-89.pdf|issn=1392-0561|title=Means of developing cultural awareness, national identity and intercultural communication skills|author=Dr. Alena Korshuk|publisher=Belarusian State University|location=Minsk|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120402103957/http://www.leidykla.vu.lt/fileadmin/Informacijos_mokslai/45/85-89.pdf|archivedate=April 2, 2012|deadurl=yes}}</ref> with other key intercultural competence tools such as the [http://www.idrinstitute.org/allegati/IDRI_t_Pubblicazioni/1/FILE_Documento.pdf Developmental Model of Intercultural Sensitivity], the [http://www.culturaldetective.com/diffsmap cultural dimensions approaches] of people such as [[Hofstede|Geert Hofstede]] or [[Trompenaars|Fons Trompenaars]] and [[Charles Hampden-Turner]]. Significant work called has been conducted on the dovetailing of Personal Leadership: Making a World of Difference and Cultural Detective.
[http://www.culturaldetective.com/services#CERT Facilitator Certification workshops] are held throughout the world and are well regarded by seasoned intercultural practitioners as well as those new to the field. Participants can receive graduate level academic credit. Many of these workshops are offered in partnership with the [https://web.archive.org/web/20111022161514/http://www.intercultural.org/cd.php Intercultural Communication Institute], and also in collaboration with [http://ihouse.berkeley.edu/ International House at the University of California Berkeley].
Coaching using the Cultural Detective method is becoming increasingly popular. A consortium of Cultural Detective authors and users has begun to offer a longer-term "B.I.G. Cultural Detective Coaching Programme".
The company publishes a "Clues to Intercultural Effectiveness" e-newsletter several times a year that includes designs, activities and tips for developing intercultural competence. There are user groups on LinkedIn and Facebook.
== References == {{Reflist|2}}
== External links == {{external links|date=July 2015}} * {{official site|http://www.culturaldetective.com}} * [http://www.diversityresources.com/cd-index.htm Diversity Resources] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20111022161514/http://www.intercultural.org/cd.php Intercultural Communication Institute] * '''Ethics/Risk/Compliance''': [http://www.compliance-training.net/ETHICS_Training.html International Association of Risk and Compliance Professionals (IARCP), "Ethics Training 3"] * '''Evaluation''': [http://aea365.org/blog/?p=4584 American Evaluation Association (AEA), "Interculturally competent evaluation tips", Dianne Hofner Saphiere] * '''Study Abroad''': [http://www.afswiki.org/index.php/AFS-specific_Cultural_Detective_Case_StudiesAFS Intercultural Programs]{{dead link|date=August 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} * '''Teaching''': [https://web.archive.org/web/20071124045337/http://www.culturaldetective.com/uwo.html University of Western Ontario Teaching Support Centre, "Some clues for decoding each other", Nadine LeGros] * '''University Staff Development''': [https://web.archive.org/web/20120425021351/http://diversity.berkeley.edu/bild/current-projects University of California Berkeley, "Bridging cultures in the workplace", Breidi Truscott]
{{Culture}}

'''Daisy B. Ba-ad''' is a playwright, stage director, composer, [[motivational speaker]] and [[life coach]] based in [[Cebu City]], Philippines. She is a Masscom graduate of [[St. Theresa's College, Cebu City]] given a special award for Outstanding Performance in Theater Arts. She is known to be at the forefront of keeping [[Cebuano theater|Cebuano Theater]] alive. Trained under professional directors Laurice Guillen, [[Gina Alajar]], Leo Martinez and New York acting coach [[Eric Morris (actor)|Eric Morris]], she is currently artistic and training director of Out of the Box Training and Productions. She also designed and mentored the Photographic/Commercial Modeling program of [https://web.archive.org/web/20081018184102/http://www.ftv.com.ph/modelschool/ftv_modelschool_mentors_baad.html Fashion TV Model School] based in the city.
Her most popular original Cebuano musical entitled ''Tall Tales Kuno!'', grant awardee of the [[National Commission for Culture and the Arts (Philippines)]] under their program for Artistic Excellence, has been staged by various organizations in Cebu. Her most recent directorial work is an original musical in English written by Jude Gitamondoc entitled [[Siddhartha (musical)|Siddhartha: A Musical Journey to Enlightenment]] produced by Buddha's Light International Association - Cebu Chapter. Its successful run at the Waterfront Pacific Ballroom, on June 6, 2007, and at the main theater of the [[Cultural Center of the Philippines]], on November 3 and 4, 2007, has paved the way for the production to be brought to Taiwan touring the cities of Taipei and Kaoshiung. Plans are underway for the Siddhartha musical to be toured in Europe, the USA, Australia and Beijing China.
Her latest directorial job was Zephryin Namuncura: The Musical, written by Jude Gitamondoc, for Don Bosco Cebu in celebration of the beatification of [[Ceferino Namuncura]]. Ba-ad is also known to have successfully used theater games in training programs she has designed for corporate groups. Her clients include Aboitiz Group of Companies, Arts Council of Cebu, Ayala Land, [[ABS-CBN]] Television Cebu, Cebu Holdings Inc., and [[Jollibee]] Foods Corp.
==Background== Daisy Ba-ad was born in Cebu City, Philippines on March 31, 1961, and is the second to the youngest in a family of nine. Her parents Melda and Domingo Ba-ad already saw the potential in her as a child. She was dubbed as the entertainer of the family at the age of four because of her ability to dance and sing upon request.
Her first exposure to theater began in kindergarten where she played support and lead roles. Her high school days were focused on developing her skills in oration, declamation, acting, singing and song composition. She was awarded a Department Medal upon graduation.
As a freshman in college taking up Mass Communications, she was voted to direct the freshman's entry to the school's Drama Festival with [[Wilfrido Ma. Guerrero]]’s [http://upreplib.tripod.com/chaperon.htm ''Wanted: Chaperon'']. They won five out of six awards including best director and best production - a first in the school's history that the freshman year would win over higher years and winning most of the awards at the same time.
Daisy became more active in college as she moved on to writing poetry and short skits for class or for official school activities and directed them. She became known as the [[Barbra Streisand]] of the school with her lip synchronization acts of Streisand's Minute Waltz, I'm Five, Jingle Bells and the like.
She also won declamation and songwriting competitions during her college days. In fact, for two successive years, she brought home the grand prize for the English and Tagalog categories of the Declamation Contest included in Inter-School Annual Literary-Musical Festival in the city. She was later given a scholarship to the Philippine Educational Theater Association's [http://www.petatheater.com/ (PETA)] Integrated Arts Workshop in Manila. She was also offered to be the moderator of the high school drama club while in her sophomore year in college. This event gave her the opportunity to start designing training modules and writing full length plays.
She was the chair of STC Bantawan theater group all throughout college and popularized the "dula-tula" form of Philippine theater in Cebu City.
==Noted directorial works==
*[[Siddhartha (musical)|SIDDHARTHA, A Musical Journey to Enlightenment]] *ZEPHRYIN, The Musical *[[Ayala Corporation|AYALA CEBU HOLDINGS INC.]], Kick Off Corporate Rally *THE [[Godspell|GODSPELL]] TAKES, Musical Culminating Activity *[[The Wiz|THE WIZ]] REVUE, Musical Culminating Activity *DREAMS, Broadway Excerpts *[[Battle of Mactan|KADAUGAN SA MACTAN]]: The Reenactment, A Festival Presentation *EVERAFTER, Culminating Activity *THE WORLD IS A STAGE, Culminating Activity *CIRQUE DU CEBU, Cebu X Awards Night *[[Mantawi Festival|THE FIRST MANTAWI FESTIVAL]] *[[The Vagina Monologues|THE VAGINA MONOLOGUES]] with [http://moniquewilson.com/ Monique Wilson] (2002 & 2004) *GOD IN MOTION, A Musical Celebrating the 50TH Year of the Salesian Community *[[Man of La Mancha|MAN OF LA MANCHA]] - Entry to the Festival of the Arts of the Arts Council of Cebu *FESTIVAL OF THE ARTS LAUNCHING, Arts Council of Cebu Foundation Inc. *SAN CARLOS: THE MUSICALE *TALL TALES!, A Daisy Ba-ad Original Musical *COMING HOME, A Musical Play *SHAKESPEAREAN RHAPSODY, Center for Intl. Education *PANAW SA KAGAHAPON, LIVE DIORAMA, [[Ayala Corporation|Cebu Holdings Inc. & Ayala Center Cebu]] *[[The King and I|THE KING & I]], Toastmasters Cebu *BINHI SA STO. NINO, DANCE DRAMA, [[Ayala Corporation|Cebu Holdings Inc. & Ayala Center Cebu]] *[[Fiddler on the Roof|FIDDLER ON THE ROOF]], Toastmasters Cebu *[[Les Misérables (musical)|LES MISERABLES]] Concert *LEON KILAT, A Musical Cebuano Play *SA MALIPAT LANG, a Cebuano adaptation of [[The Fantasticks]]

revision.text:
'''Dual-coding theory''', a theory of cognition, was hypothesized by [[Allan Paivio]] of the University of Western Ontario in 1971. In developing this theory, Paivio used the idea that the formation of mental images [[picture superiority effect|aids]] in learning (Reed, 2010). According to Paivio, there are two ways a person could expand on learned material: verbal associations and visual imagery. Dual-coding theory postulates that both visual and verbal information is used to represent information (Sternberg, 2003). Visual and verbal information are processed differently and along distinct channels in the human mind, creating separate representations for information processed in each channel. The mental codes corresponding to these representations are used to organize incoming information that can be acted upon, stored, and retrieved for subsequent use. Both visual and verbal codes can be used when recalling information (Sternberg, 2003). For example, say a person has stored the stimulus concept "dog" as both the word 'dog' and as the image of a dog. When asked to recall the stimulus, the person can retrieve either the word or the image individually, or both simultaneously. If the word is recalled, the image of the dog is not lost and can still be retrieved at a later point in time. The ability to code a stimulus two different ways increases the chance of remembering that item compared to if the stimulus was only coded one way.
There has been controversy to the limitations of the dual-coding theory. Dual-coding theory does not take into account the possibility of cognition being mediated by something other than words and images. Not enough research has been done to determine if words and images are the only way we remember items, and the theory would not hold true if another form of codes were discovered (Pylyshyn, 1973). Another limitation of the dual-coding theory is that it is only valid for tests on which people are asked to focus on identifying how concepts are related (Reed, 2010). If associations between a word and an image cannot be formed, it is much harder to remember and recall the word at a later point in time. While this limits the effectiveness of the dual-coding theory, it is still valid over a wide range of circumstances and can be used to improve memory (Reed, 2010).
==Types of codes==
'''Analogue codes''' are used to mentally represent images. Analogue codes retain the main perceptual features of whatever is being represented, so the images we form in our minds are highly similar to the physical stimuli. They are a near-exact representation of the physical stimuli we observe in our environment, such as trees and rivers (Sternberg, 2003).
'''Symbolic codes''' are used to form mental representations of words. They represent something conceptually, and sometimes, arbitrarily, as opposed to perceptually. Similar to the way a watch may represent information in the form of numbers to display the time, symbolic codes represent information in our mind in the form of arbitrary symbols, like words and combinations of words, to represent several ideas. Each symbol (x, y, 1, 2, etc.) can arbitrarily represent something other than itself. For instance, the letter x is often used to represent more than just the concept of an x, the 24th letter of the alphabet. It can be used to represent a variable x in mathematics, or a multiplication symbol in an equation. Concepts like multiplication can be represented symbolically by an "x" because we arbitrarily assign it a deeper concept. Only when we use it to represent this deeper concept does the letter "x" carry this type of meaning.
== Support ==
===Evidence from psychological research=== Many researchers have agreed that only words and images are used in mental representation (Pylyshyn, 1973). Supporting evidence shows that memory for some verbal information is enhanced if a relevant visual is also presented or if the learner can imagine a visual image to go with the verbal information. Likewise, visual information can often be enhanced when paired with relevant verbal information, whether real-world or imagined (Anderson & Bower, 1973). This theory has been applied to the use of multimedia presentations. Because multimedia presentations require both spatial and verbal working memory, individuals dually code information presented and are more likely to recall the information when tested at a later date (Brunye, Taylor, & Rapp, 2008). Moreover, studies that have been conducted on abstract and concrete words have also found that the participants remembered concrete words better than the abstract words (Hargis & Gickling, 1978; Sadoski, 2005; Yui, Ng, & Perera-W.A., 2017).
Paivio found that participants when shown a rapid sequence of pictures as well as a rapid sequence of words and later asked to recall the words and pictures, in any order, were better at recalling images. Participants, however, more readily recalled the sequential order of the words, rather than the sequence of pictures. These results supported Paivio's hypothesis that verbal information is processed differently from visual information and that verbal information was superior to visual information when sequential order was also required for the memory task (Paivio, 1969). Lee Brooks conducted an experiment that provided additional support for two systems for memory. He had participants perform either a visual task, where they had to view a picture and answer questions about the picture, or a verbal task, where they listened to a sentence and were then asked to answer questions pertaining to the sentence. To respond to the questions, participants were asked to either respond verbally, visually, or manually. Through this experiment, Brooks found that interference occurred when a visual perception was mixed with manipulation of the visual task, and verbal responses interfere with a task involving a verbal statement to be manually manipulated. This supported the idea of two codes used to mentally represent information (Sternberg 2003).
[[Working memory]] as proposed by [[Alan Baddeley]] includes a two-part processing system with a visuospatial sketchpad and a phonological loop which essentially maps to Paivio's theory.
Dual-coding theories complement a dual-route theory of [[Reading (activity)|reading]]. When people read written information, dual-route theory contends that the readers access [[Orthography|orthographic]] and [[Phonology|phonological]] information to recognize [[Word (linguistics)|words]] in the [[writing]].
Paivio's work has implications for literacy, visual [[mnemonics]], idea generation, [[Human Performance Technology|HPT]], human factors, interface design, as well as the development of educational materials among others. It also has implications for, and counterparts in, [[cognitive sciences]] and computational cognitive modeling (in the form of dual process cognitive models and so on; e.g., Anderson, 2005; Just et al., 2004, Sun, 2002). It also has had implications for cognitive robotics.
===Cognitive neuroscience support===
Two different methods have been used to identify the regions involved in visual perception and visual imagery. First, [[functional magnetic resonance imaging]] (fMRI) is used to measure [[cerebral blood flow]], which allows researchers to identify the amount of glucose and oxygen being consumed by a specific part of the brain, with an increase in blood flow providing a measure of brain activity. Second, an [[event related potential]] (ERP) can be used to show the amount of electrical brain activity that is occurring due to a particular stimulus. Researchers have used both methods to determine which areas of the brain are active with different stimuli, and results have supported the dual-coding theory. Other research has been done with [[positron emission tomography]] (PET) scans and fMRI to show that participants had improved memory for spoken words and sentences when paired with an image, imagined or real, and showed increased brain activation to process abstract words not easily paired with an image.
==Alternative theory==
Dual-coding theory is not accepted by everyone. [[John Robert Anderson (psychologist)|John Anderson]] and [[Gordon H. Bower|Gordon Bower]] proposed an alternative method – the propositional theory – of how knowledge is mentally represented. The propositional theory claims that mental representations are stored as propositions rather than as images. Here, proposition is defined as the meaning that underlies the relationship between concepts (Sternberg, 2003). This theory states that images occur as a result of other cognitive processes because knowledge is not represented in the form of images, words, or symbols.
The [[common coding theory]] has also been proposed as an alternative to dual coding theory. The common coding theory looks at how things we see and hear are connected to our motor actions. It claims that there is a common code that is shared between perceiving something and the respective motor action.
== See also ==
* [[Multimedia learning]]
== References == * Anderson, J. R. (2005). Cognitive Psychology and its implications. New York: Worth Publishers. * Anderson, J. R. & Bower, G. H. (1973). Human associative memory. Washington, DC: Winston. * Baddeley, A. D. (1986). Working memory. Oxford: Oxford University Press. * Brunye, T. T., Taylor, H. A., & Rapp, D. N. (2008). Repetition and dual coding in procedural multimedia presentations. ''Applied Cognitive Psychology, 22,'' 877-895. * Denis, M. and Mellet, E. (2002). Neural bases of image and language interactions. [[International Journal of Psychology]], 37 (4), 204-208. * Hargis, C. H., & Gickling, E. E. (1978). The function of imagery in word recognition development. The Reading Teacher, 31(8), 870-874. * Just, M. et al. (2004). Imagery in sentence comprehension: an fMRI study. NeuroImage 21, 112-124. * Mayer, R. E. & Moreno, R. (2003). Nine ways to reduce cognitive load in multimedia learning. Educational Psychologist, 38(1), 43-52. * Moreno, R., & Mayer, R. E. (2000). A coherence effect in multimedia learning: the case for minimizing irrelevant sounds in the design of multimedia instructional messages. Journal of Educational Psychology, 92, 117-125. * Yui L, Ng R, Perera-W.A. H. (2017). Concrete vs abstract words – what do you recall better? A study on dual coding theory. PeerJ Preprints 5:e2719v1https://doi.org/10.7287/peerj.preprints.2719v1 * Paivio, A (1969). Mental Imagery in associative learning and memory. Psychological Review, 76(3), 241-263. * Paivio, A (1971). Imagery and verbal processes. New York: Holt, Rinehart, and Winston. * Paivio, A (1986). Mental representations: a dual coding approach. Oxford. England: Oxford University Press. *{{cite book | last=Sternberg | first=Robert J. | authorlink=Robert J. Sternberg | title=Cognitive psychology fourth edition | publisher=Thomson Wadsworth | year=2006 | pages=234–36 | isbn=0-534-51421-9}} * Pylyshyn, Z. W. (1973). What the mind's eye tells the mind's brain: A critique of mental imagery. ''Psychological Bulletin, 80,'' 1-24. * Reed, S. K. (2010). Cognition: Theories and application (8th ed.). Belmont, CA: Wadsworth Cengage Learning. * Sadoski, M., Willson, V. L., Holcomb, A., & Boulware-Gooden, R. (2005). Verbal and nonverbal predictors of spelling performance. Journal of Literacy Research, 36, 461–478. * Sternberg, R. J. (2003). Cognitive theory (3rd ed.). Belmont, CA: Thomson Wadsworth. * Sun, R. (2002). Duality of the Mind. Mahwah, NJ: Lawrence Erlbaum Associates. * Thomas, N. J.T., "Mental imagery", ''The Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy (Winter 2011 Edition),'' Edward N Zalta (ed.).
==External links== * [http://www.thereferentialprocess.org/theory/multiple-code-theory Multiple Code Theory]
